reviewText:
This is my attempt at informing the community who already own Darksiders 2 and is not actually a review of the game itself. For the sake of being able to post I will recommend the game as the game itself is a good game, but this practice of keeping consumers in the dark needs to stop! So if you are a new customer who doesn't own Darksiders 2 just ignore the rest I am about to write for the game is excellent and Vigil Games deserves your money in order to make Darksiders 3. Now If you already own Darksiders 2 then save your money and redeem your free key through this web page. http://ds2dekeyredeem.nordicgames.at/
I had no idea this was even a thing and I really wish I was informed of this, but sadly I found out about this just now after a friend got his free copy. Nordic Games not mentioning this for Steam users is shady as all Helheim and it is obvious they did this to score more sales out of us loyal fans by keeping us in the dark about this while also making themselves feel smug and charitable by having a web page at all. I mean just look at the damn web page! Doesn't that look shady!?

If you are in doubt whether this is legitimate or not then I don't blame you, you can see my own breakdown to this news in both these forum posts.
http://steamcommunity.com/app/50650/discussions/0/492379439692091931/
http://steamcommunity.com/app/388410/discussions/0/492379439692084930/

And you know what sucks the most? They didn't even let me have my free copy when I tried to redeem it because I already owned the Deathinitive Edition, how messed up is that!? Not even a copy to gift to a friend...

Welcome FateWeaver! ( SteamUserID: 76561197971286820 )
You own Darksiders II

Nordic Games

Enjoy playing it they say, how the Helheim can I enjoy playing it when they hoodwinked me and the rest of us loyal fans like this!?

Write a positive review they said... The nerve on these people... Well they can forget it!!! Instead I am informing you the reader about this so you can avoid feeding Nordic Game another shady and undeserved sale!!! Stick it to them where it hurts so they will learn to not take advantage of their fanbase community!!!

reviewText:
This review is written with assumption you already played the original Darksiders 2 before.

Deathinitive is a remake of Darksiders 2. It doesn't have new content whatsoever, but offers better experience. And yes, definitely better in every aspects than the original Darksiders 2. Graphically it's good, and when you max it the game's very good looking. I am playing with 840m toaster-like graphic card and have decent FPS so far with all maxed settings. Though, the game still suffers from random stuttering even when I'm using public beta, but so far so good, not that horrible. Crashes from ALT+TAB-ing also still present, but hopefully it will be fixed.

The game is made with controller in mind, so you'd be better off playing with controller. Dinput controller isn't supported, but you can x360ce it. Xinput is supported natively.

This version does NOT need any DLC purchased to get full experience, as everything is integrated. The only DLC being sold is OST, which is in 320 kbps, and it's the same as OST DLC from previous title.

As a whole, there are things that must be addressed notably performance issues, but as it stands it deserves thumbs up from me.

Here's wishing Darksiders 3 coming for real.

reviewText:
Darksiders and its sequel remain some of my favorite games from the previous generation. The first game was clearly and deliberately derivative of some of the best titles in history, Zelda and God of War chief among them. The dungeon crawling and puzzles were top notch, as was the sense of progression and the combat, while simple, was visceral and satisfying in a way that Zelda's never was. As important, however, was the story which was filled with engaging characters and a lore that was much more interesting than something based on Biblical mythology (not an uncommon road to tread) had any right to be. War, Samael, Vulgrim, Ulthane and Uriel were all extremely memorable characters.

And oh, that ending.

Darksiders II was one of the first games in years I'd preordered. I was looking forward to the game largely because I honestly never thought it would come when I finished the first game. Somehow, in spite of all of that anticipation, I was not disappointed. The world that Darksiders II presents is incredible. It isn't vast or filled to the brim with random events like many open world games; in essence, it's not one; but it is absolutely beautiful in its creativity and heart. It's clear that the game was crafted with care and that the developers and artists weren't just making set pieces but building something beyond the ruined Earth we see in the first game -- a world apart from the one we know.

The game expands on many concepts from the original. The combat is less heavy than the original's but is sped up considerably, with Death feeling more akin to Dante than Kratos which is very fitting for his lithe appearance. The fixed equipment from the original is replaced by a randomized loot system -- one of the game's few missteps, as this results in a less satisfying feeling of progression or, when all  is said and done, completion.

The story remains engaging, introducing a whole slew of new characters with some familiar faces resurfacing throughout. The only negative is that the ending feels a bit lackluster as it doesn't really progress the story significantly from the original, though there are heavy implications for what's to come next.

That all leads me to the Deathinitive Edition. The launch of the game was marred somewhat by a crashing issue which was resolved within a day of release and a large swath of people complaining because their discount was less than others'. Removing those non-issues, the DE itself stands as a fantastic rendition and a worthy upgrade to the original. The implementation of the DLC weapons and armor make them feel like real, substantial items in the game world rather than throwaway trinkets which are useless within a few hours' gametime. I would have liked the Story DLC to somehow have been implemented directly into the campaign however I see how that would have been difficult.

Performance, after some beta patches and hotfixes, has been noticeably improved over the original and the game looks GORGEOUS by comparison. Initially, the picture may come off as a bit less saturated and in some areas that's simply the case (the opening of the game is the most heavily impacted by this so far, I think) but much of this is due to the much more realistic lighting. Overall, I think it adds depth and a slight touch of realism that really makes the game's world breathe. A simple improvement is that metallic objects now have a metallic sheen -- it's incredible how much this small change has impacted the visuals but in an odd way it adds weight and density to Death's armor and weapons.

Overall, I can't recommend this version enough, especially to current owners who currently get an extremely steep discount. For new owners, this is still among the best games of last generation and this is simply the best version of the game available. I'm really excited to see what Nordic and Gunfire do with this series moving forward.

reviewText:
THQ’s demise sent ripples through the industry, but few felt it as keenly as Vigil Games. They had just released Darksiders II, and things were looking up for the studio as they started work on Warhammer 40,000: Dark Millennium. And suddenly everything went pear shaped. A bidding war for the individual studios and their intellectual properties emerged as THQ began to fold. Zero bids were made for Vigil or its IP, much to everyone’s surprise. Crytek swooped in post-collapse and formed a new studio called Crytek USA, snapping up many ex-Vigil folks in the process.

Unfortunately, Vigil’s luck didn’t hold as Crytek’s own financial woes were visited upon the new crew. In early 2014, founder David Adams and 20 of his core team members left and founded their own studio — a chance to take control of their destiny once again. Hooking up with the owners of the Darksiders IP, Nordic Games, the first objective of the newly-formed Gunfire Games was plainly visible — Remastering Darksiders II. Could this re-introduction pave a path to continue the fantastic storyline, or is Darksiders II Deathinitive Edition just another bump on a very rough road for this team?

Prior to the events of the first game, Earth is desolate. One of the four horsemen, War, has been condemned by the council – his judgement soon to be passed. He was beckoned to the human realm, but there was no call; leading to the extinction of the human race, and destruction and demonic renovation of the realm. Death, War’s brother, believes him to be innocent, and willing to do anything to prove him as such, he seeks the Crowfather, keeper of many secrets, so he may find his brother’s redemption.Things go awry and Death is defeated; his former trinket bearing unreaped souls broken, embedded into his chest, and sent away to the realm of the Makers. He seeks the Tree of Life for answers, but the land is plagued by Corruption.

Darksiders II may have a greater focus on story than the first, and its dialogue and writing are superb, but it’s practically nonexistent. The story lacks any sense of urgency, making it stale and unexciting. There’s not much to look forward to when progressing the story except visiting new locales and new dungeons. Even when the story picks up and begins to catch your interest, it’s predictable and you might be caught up in the numerous side quests. It’s too simplistic and follows the paradigms of Action-Adventure games a la Legend of Zelda (go from point A to point B to acquire item A to open door Z).

What Darksiders II does accomplish is having a likeable protagonist with exceptional delivery. Voiced by Michael Wincott, Death is a cynical, witty, and overall charming character. He constantly engages in banter with the other characters, eliciting a few chuckles here and there and shining some light on an otherwise boring and dreary story. His motivations are unclear, however. While he does have a rationale for why he must put a stop to the big bad, it’s never stated why he fights for his brother’s innocence. Whether it’s for brotherly love or for his sense of justice, it’s left up to the interpretation of the player, harming the integrity of the story and its writers.

It’s also worth mentioning the change in scenery is quite vast in Darksiders II as compared to the first. While the first game took place in a post-apocalyptic city, the Makers’ realm explored in this entry is much more fantasy. It feels odd transitioning between two radically different settings, and while there may be some answers as to who’s who and what’s what from the first game, it would be better if it were left ambiguous and saved for a later entry. It changes up much of what the first Darksiders established and creates even more questions, such as why some characters are where they are now.

Darksiders as a series has always attempted to mimic other franchises. From gameplay reminiscent of God of War, dungeon exploring akin to the Legend of Zelda, climbing and wall running similar to Prince of Persia, and a loot system nearly ripped from Diablo, DSII does much to accentuate itself from the imitated franchises. New to Darksiders II are its RPG mechanics. While the first game played like a normal Hack ‘n Slash where you merely traversed lands and were only rewarded with currency upon defeating enemies, the world has been opened up for greater exploration and you now gain EXP in order to level up.

Death is much more nimble and acrobatic than War, the tutorial will prove. He’s much faster, has a longer dodge distance, and his moves are more extravagant and his arsenal versatile. Given the loot system, Death has a larger variety of sub-weapons. From bucklers and arm blades with swift strikes, to hammers and axes with slow swings, you are given more options in how you may want to arm yourself. This offers some layer of adaptability for the player, allowing them to choose a specific playstyle. Depending on weight classification, they mostly have unique moves but come sub-varieties, they aren’t much different apart from charge attacks. This is lackluster, despite the initial concept being a welcome one.

Once you’ve acquired enough experience points, Death will level up. When done, not only will his base stats like ATK and DEF increase, but he will also receive a skill point. New to the game is the implementation of the skill tree, where these new points may be invested into so to acquire new skills and power them up. However, this tree is split into two categories: physical magic, focused on attacks and buffing your stats, and normal magic or spellcasting, dependent on your MP and scaling with a stat called Arcane.

It’s worth mentioning some of my problems with how Death handles. While combat is greatly diversified with the introduction of the loot and equipment system, after a few hours of play, it’s revealed just how shallow the combat is. Even after acquiring new moves, I still found myself using the same, few tricks throughout my playthrough. Enemies were impossible to stagger, the only ounce of difficulty coming because of that. Being a Hack ‘n Slash, a genre known for pulling off crazy combos, it’s unfortunate, as the action loses its momentum as a result.

Death also seems to have problems when scaling and running on walls. His movements feel sluggish and unresponsive to player input; taking about 0.5 sec before he’ll do what you commanded him, causing some headaches in certain sections of the game. While some rubble and walls may seem like they can be scaled, Death seems to be unable to. There are invisible walls, shrouded by debris of fallen ruin placed where you may not need to go and even some minor walls in accessible areas aren’t climbable without the grips indicating climbable sections. It’s annoying and inconvenient, especially grating considering that Death is capable of much greater acrobatic feats.

Possibly the most memorable part of Darksiders II: Deathinitive Edition are its visuals and soundtrack. Come the Deathinitive edition of the game, textures have vastly been improved and new lighting has been implemented for much more seamless and beautiful environments than the original. While this update to visuals wasn’t necessary (as the game was already gorgeous), it lends to a fantastic representation of the merits of a more stylized artstyle, especially in a saturated market of more realistic games. The orchestrated score in the game is phenomenal. It lends an ‘epic’ feeling to the game, making it more immersive and more like an actual journey. It sets a tone for the story, and while the player experience may vary, Death’s fight for his brother’s redemption is undoubtedly felt through the music.

Darksiders II is one of the more memorable Hack and Slash titles with breathtaking, mythical settings supported by interesting characters, fascinating lore, and snappy gameplay.

reviewText:
Darksiders 2 is probably one of my favorite aRPGs in recent years/ Althought the Deathinitive Edition does currently have some performance issues, the support that Nordic Games offered for Red Faction: Guerilla makes me optimistic that they will continue to work with the community and patch it to work properly.

I enjoyed the original Darksiders, but the sequel expands and improves on every aspect. Some quick comments.

- The graphics are indeed much improved. Crisp, clean, and the cel-shaded inspired art style is lovely with the overhauled lighting.

-The music, as in the original version of this game, is outstanding, and easily some of Jesper Kyd's best work. Equal parts gothic and celtic inspirations make the soundtrack well worth remembering.

-The voice acting, and the characterization of Death in particular, is exceptional. My biggest issue with the original Darksiders was that War was basically a grimdark Space Marine. Death, on the other hand, is always handy with a bit of much needed snark, sarcasm, and even the occasional moment of sensitivity. This is the reaper as I like to envision him.

- The gameplay is quick, satisfyingly punchy, and has a gentle learning curve with a high plateau. Playing with various specs and active abilities is quite enjoyable, and finding an upgrade for your equipment is always nice.

Overall, I would wholeheartedly recommend the Deathinitive Edition for newcomers to the series. For anyone who already owns and has played the original release of the game, you will not find anything new here, but revisiting a fine game in revised form is very enjoyable.

reviewText:
Works fine for me. 2500K @ 4.3Ghz, GTX970. Running DSR 1.5x at a constant 60fps.

Triple Buffering: On (this fixed some minor camera stutter).

£5 for a new lighting system, higher res textures, all of the DLC and to support the development of Darksiders 3 is alright by me.

The developers themselves are talking to the community to fix issues rather than the norm of employing some numpty as a community manager who then goes on a power trip censoring all complaints. I have confidence that within the next 1-2 weeks the vast majority of issues will be fixed.

This is a different situation to the Arkham Knight fiasco. Here the developers care about their product, are actively engaged with the community and have been working and releasing beta patches throughout the weekend. I hope those who have thumbed down the game will reconsider their review once the fixes are out.

reviewText:
I got this game for free, as I had the Darksiders Bundle from before.
And I must say that the difference this makes is awesome. The game used to look nice but the the textures always were an eyesore. Now however, with the updated graphics in this one, it really is looking awesome. Much better than I expected when I saw the patch notes.

The downside is that its a lot more demanding to run now. I am getting about 70 FPS with everything maxed on 1440p resolution. For most people this will not be an issue, but I thought it was worth mentioning since I recall the original running much better. I have a GTX980, 8GB ram and a 4790K Intel CPU. I am playing the game at less than Max shadows just and am getting about 90 FPS.

One of the major flags for this game is that its not a very good console port. The FOV is set to less than 60, and it has caused me plenty of migraines making it neigh unplayable. This alone would have made me give it a not recommended review, but recently I found that there are cheat engine tables made by the community that let you change the FOV to something more manageable, and It has made the game playable for me. So people who get motion sickness need to be aware that on default settings, this will make you sick. However using the cheat table is a workaround that does work.

Once you can get past these problems, Darksiders 2 is really an awesome game underneath. I love the story, the art design, and most of all the voice acting. The gameplay is very fast faced, and the maps are huge with little to no loading times. I am not quite sure if it is worth purchasing at full price, if you already have Deathsiders 2, but if you don't, then I would heartily recommend purchasing and playing this game.

I see a lot of people saying that Nordic should have offered the game for free to everyone who had Darksiders 2, and not just an 80% off discount. Or that they should have better ways to check for DLC since a lot of people bought it individually and not in a pack. While I can agree with this sentiment, I still think its a bit harsh to blame Nordic for this. Their last publisher went bankrupt and they spent a lot of cash to buy back the rights for this game and got most of their team together. Calling this game a patch that should have been free is simply wrong. It makes a massive difference to the look of the game, and I for one am glad they did it even if I would have had to purchase this game again.

Edit: Made an edit following the second patch that fixes the mouse sensitivity in aim mode.

Parere personale:

In questa versione definitiva, troviamo tutti i dlc disponibili, che aggiungono parecchie ore alla normale storia, oltre a tanti extra più che graditi.
Graficamente, forse si sente e lo si vede che si stratta di un gioco old gen, ma su pc prestanti, in 4K, è veramente molto bello!

Considerando anche il prezzo non troppo elevato, questa versione con tutti i dlc è veramente da considerare soprattutto se non avete mai giocato al buon vecchio Darksiders II

reviewText:
Yes I was one of those who were fortunate to of come into Darksiders late in the game. I bought the complete pack, hence I was upgraded to Deathfinitive. I pity those who were loyal from the beginning and bought each DLC seperately, it doesn't see fair, really.

However, this game is epic, it's huge and beautiful, it's not just the deathfinitive of Darksiders, it's the definitive of so many other games in the same genre e.g. Prince of Persia, DMC, Zelda, etc...

I think the game is really underrated, I've found the game to be accessible and challenging, I have had to checkout a walkthrough or two and haven't finished the game, but I certainly keep coming back and find that the game is quite relaxing, rather than frustrating.

The maps are big, the story is straightforward and the voice acting is superb. The gameplay is typical with some neat additions like grappling, summoning, clone thingies, etc..

All I have to say is if you a new to this game you won't,be dissapointed and I'm really sorry to those who were loyal from the beginning, sincerely.

reviewText:
UPDATE: A recent patch seems to have alleviated a great deal of the stuttering issues I had. Game is playable for me now which is a good thing. However I'd say if you're the type to want the best possible performance out of your games you may not get a great experience out of the Deathinitive" edition of Darksiders II. The game still feels a little sluggish overall and I'd only recommend this game if you can overlook that. Given the recommended system specs for this game I think it should run a great deal smoother than it actually does.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
I honestly wish I could recommend this game. They've fixed the crash to desktop bug that a great deal of reviews were negative for but one thing they've yet to fix is the game's overall performance. The fps drops and stutter in places are supremely annoying to the point where it's barely playable.

This review will be subject to change depending on if/when Nordic decide to fix the performance issues but currently I simply would not recommend this game."

reviewText: Loved Darksiders II when it launched, sure it was buggy but the combat felt awesome, the worlds were among the most creative I have seen and Death was simply a badass. That being said, DO NOT BUY THIS! I was hesitant but in the end willing to buy the graphical upgrade for the $6 for owning the games previously (why we didn't get it free like those who paid less for the franchise bundle later in the games life, despite owning the same content is anyone's guess.) But as soon as I upped the settings to MODERN DAY STANDARDS a.k.a. 1080p SHOCKER! the game refueses to load. It crashes EVERY time without fail when I try to laod the game, and it seems as though I am far from the only one, in fact I have yet to hear an instance where this has not happened. How did something as HUGE as the game NOT WORKING when it is set to a resolution that has been a standard for roughly a decade get past their QA? This is utterly unaccatable. And the worst part? You can't even buy the older version now, at least that one worked more than 0.1% of the time

reviewText:
Darksiders II Review
Darksiders II is a much better game than it's predecessor which was basically a God of War / Zelda mash up with low quantity of new or original ideas. Darksiders II is a Borderlands of 3rd person action games, it incorporates full skill trees, leveling and loot systems while preserving fun combat and puzzle solving from the original. It still has some flaws/drawbacks, some of them are still there from the first part, which is really disappointing, but overall it's a pretty original and one-of-a-kind tittle currently on the market which makes it a pretty much must play for any 3rd person action fan.

I'll list some of the most prominent positive/negative points along with a couple of neutral ones.

Positive:
Fun combat system with variety of weapons and options to destroy your foes.
2 Full skill trees, basically warrior and mage build with variety of skills to choose from.
Good diablo-styled loot system with a ton of randomly generated items along with some Legendary items to obtain.
Possessed Weapon system which lets you craft a weapon you desire by feeding it with other items.
Cool dungeon design with many puzzles to solve and secrets to find along your path.
Semi-open world with a bunch of locations, huge and small.
Many enemies, bosses and even some rare creatures to fight, much less recolors" than in previous part
date: basically every part/map of the game features it's own unique enemies.\nA battle arena called The Crucible with 100 waves of enemies and a secret boss.\nNG+ where you can level up Death even further
recommended: try other build and find more powerful items.\nNeutral:\nSub-weapon variety could be better
hoursPlayed: it's better than in Darksiders but still kind of lackluster in my eyes
voteText: although some people might find it sufficient.\nMove list could be wider
helpfulPercent: but again some people might think it's more than enough.\nMany side quests
votesHelpful: but they are a chore to do usually
votesTotal: although you get awesome rewards for doing most of them.\nStory is sub par
votesFunny: it just here to entertain you to some degree.\nGraphically and stylistically it's the same as predecessor
commentsCount: it looks cool
column16: but I personally think that it doesn't fit "Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse" theme much. To each their own
column17: I suppose.\nNegative:\nDifficulty level is pretty low
column18: after 1st chapter you won't find much challenge and Death just snowballs out of control.\nNG+ attributes such as health/wrath steal makes game even easier.\nCollectibles. Tons of them. I usually like to find hidden stuff especially in this kind of games
column20: they overdid it this time. There are more then 250 collectible items in this game
column21: some of them are obscurely hidden and trust me - even if you'll try your best to find them
column22: in the end there will be a dozen that you've missed and good luck figuring out which one of them you actually missed... It could be "okay" if those were just filler collectibles like in Dead Island for instance
column23: but you'll get awesome rewards and achievements. I am not saying collectibles are bad
column24: I just think there're just way too many of them.\nPuzzles are dumbed down
column25: Darksiders got me thinking really hard on some of it's puzzles
column26: while in Darksiders II I don't even remember a really tough puzzle where I had to think more than a few seconds before solving it.\nAlthough there is a teleport option to move between locations
column28:
especially big ones could be a chore since Death runs kind of slow and ultimately you'll find yourself using "dodge" move over and over again just to speed up the process.
Overall it's a good and somewhat original 3rd person action with decent replayability. Definitely a must play for the fans of this genre.

8/10.

Deathinitive Edition Review
I don't think there was a necessity to make a remaster for this game since it's not that old and it ran 1080p@60FPS on PC anyway.

Just recently did a NG+ run on a new difficulty level
column29:
I'll just state my observations here:

Textures look much better now.
Lighting changed in many areas
column30: causes some flickering and glitches sometimes.\nMenus/UI is more responsive now. Loads faster.\nAll previous DLC items are now unique drops from certain bosses and/or hidden chests
column31:
weapons are now scales with your level. Some of the DLC weapons changed to possessed weapons.
DLC campaigns unlocks after a certain boss has been defeated.
Less loot drops from chests.
Deathinitive difficulty level is not much of a challenge for a NG+ character
column32:
harder for a NG character though.
Poor optimization. Frame drops in certain locations for no apparent reasons.
Crashes on damaging multi-hit abilities/moves. You can definitely complete the game but fighting in The Crucible could be a pain. As of 01.12.2015 it's still hasn't been fixed.
A decent remaster
column33: but needs some fixes before it could be really good. I thinks it's a shame that they pulled vanilla off of steam store before finalizing this release."

reviewText:
*Update* The latest series of patches that the developer has released has improved the performance quite a lot, vsync appears to be functioning properly now and the triple buffering/shadow optimizations have knocked my fps up to 60 in graphic intensive areas. it's still not perfect as there are still occasional stutters but i can safely say that it is playable now. And it is actually quite visually impressive compared to the regular version. Thinking about changing the review if we recieve any more patches

It seems the developers increased a lot of the graphical eye-candy but did nothing to ensure the game engine could handle the extra eye candy that they added.

They could have at least updated the renderer from DX9 to DX11 or made the game 64 bit supported or something like that

This game has extreme issues with its vsync/refresh rate/buffering system as well. They really needs someone with development know-how to look into this issue. This also existed in the regular darksiders2 but not nearly as bad as this.

reviewText:
-CHECK YOUR DRIVERS BEFORE YOU RULE THIS GAME AS BROKEN- DETAILS BELOW!

So, I got this game with the discount for Darksiders II owners (60% I believe) which seems just fine to me as I never got to play the DLCs, so $12 for all the DLC plus revamped graphics seems about right. I got this game for $3 on ♥♥♥ anyways, so I ended up paying $15. Not bad,

I absolutely LOVE Darksiders, so Deathinitive Edition was the perfect excuse to play them again; I had the first one on Steam too, so I'm playing it right now before I go into DS2DE. If you read reviews and comments everywhere, people seem to be having LOTS of problems with the game, so I wanted to try and see if that was true. At first the game ran absolutely broken, with insane stuttering and 15FPS even in 720p with no shadows, AA nor AO. Having a Skylake 2.5Ghz i7 and a GTX970M, that was absolutely impossible to believe. So, I downloaded the original DS2 (As I still have it on my library) and surprising enough, the game ran like ♥♥♥♥ as well. So after all the troubleshooting, I decided to roll back to the last MSI certified drivers for this PC (353.74) just because that was my last TS step... and now the game runs at solid 90FPS 90% of the time, 1080p, full shadows, AA and AO.

So, in the end, it was a driver problem! I don't know how many of you are having problems with this, but if you're one of them, please try using older drivers, as it seems that Nvidia's latest are ♥♥♥♥. Dunno about AMD users tho, but for me this did the trick.

Oh, and these games are amazing, please do yourself a favor and play them. They are as unique as it gets, and instant classics from last gen. Here's for DS3 soon!

reviewText:
Love this game. Bought the original and even with a couple problems thought it was a great game except for the really low rez textures, now they have fixed that with this version . The new lighting and better shadows make the game look much better.

I am not having a huge problem with stuttering, the only times it happens for me is when I go into a new area or the game saves. Their are a couple of things that will reduce the stuttering  to almost completely gone.  One is setting maximum pre-rendered fames to 1 in the Nvidia control panel under Manage 3d Settings, another is to foece Vsync through Nvidia control panel under Mange 3d Settings and turn off vsync in game. I think the in game Vsync is addaptive Vsync.

Also the high anti aliasing setting is broken, so you will need to set it to medium, the devs have said this will be fixed in the next patch.

Some people are upset about not getting it free even though they bought all the content that is in the franchise pack. Well Idid too but I got them really cheap. I spent maybe twenty dollars for everything including buying this version, can't complain and neither should many of the people that bought the games and dlc really cheap. The ones that paid full price for the games and dlc maybe should contact the developer.

All in all a great game that I am enjoying all over again with much better graphics in my opinion.

reviewText:
The new remastered version of Dark Siders II brings the game on a ways more adequate level of resolution. Even though there are still some minor claylike textures the overall look has improved by alot! I have been playing through the first 4 Dungeons atm and the new lava and light effects such as the sunglare rays are kinda impressive for a remastered game of 2012.

This new edition also contains a new difficulty mode called 'Deathinitive' which seems to be the next level above 'Apocalyptic'. I didn't try that one yet but this will be surely my next target on my 2nd save.

There are currently some minor technical issues such as a too fast horizontal aim cursors if you play with Mouse and Keyboard but as far as I have heard the developers are already fixing that issue so it's gonna be history within a few days.

By buying or getting this edition you will also obtain all the DLC's for the game such as 'The Abyssal Forge' and 'Demon Lord Belial' as well as the weapon dlc's to get a small headstart in your first New Game save. I can't wait to see the new remastered models of the Guardian and the Archon so I'm deathinitively (badumtsss) gonna finish that game once again.
Praise to the chosen of the light!

reviewText:
I will only talk about the game itself. Yes, its distribution was a bit... weird and I paid 6 bucks myself, desprite owning it already. Yeah, 6 bucks, buuhuu, what a loss...

Seriously though, lets talk about the game:
Darksiders 2 in general is a great game. If you enjoyed the first Darksiders, you will like this one too. I still prefer the first one, since the odd item system feels out of place and the story isnt as gripping. The gameplay is fun though and playing Wars more agile brother has a neat, very different feel to it. I was never any good at blocking, so the dodge-centered approach comes natural to me. The artstyle is beautiful, the environments are diverse for the most parts and the world and lore are very well made. I really like the whole Hell-Heaven-Apocalypse-stuff, because it takes all the cool myths of christianity without adding the boring parts (looking at you, new testament).

So in short:
+ very satisfying combat
+ gorgeous artstyle
+ great world/lore
+ You play as one of the four horsemen!!

- story drags on sometimes
- awkward, diablo-like item-system

The Deathinitive Edition:
Now, what's different with the new version. First of all, the DLCs are fully included and woven into the main game, making them feel like natural parts of the game, which is the best a DLC can hope for. The visuals are enhanced too, but you wouldn't notice that unless you really look for it. The best thing might be the overhauled loot-distribution, that makes the obsolete item-system a bit less out of place. The menus are still awful though. Man, why doesn't anyone put any thought in menus any more...

So, all in all, if you havent played Darksiders before, play the first one, love it, come back and play the second game too. If you have played the first and have not played this one... seriously? what the hell is wrong with you? If you own Darksiders 2 already, you don't have to get the update. I think it was worth my 6 bucks, but i am a bit of a fanboy.

reviewText:
Just finished my first playthrough - this review will be mainly focused on how I think this game compares to the original darksiders.

Although I wasn't as immediately engrosed in the story as I was with the original darksiders, darksiders 2 grew on me as I progressed past the initial levels, where the game picks up pace. I'd say that, compared to the first game, the story arc is less fleshed out although I haven't completed any of the side campaigns/ quests as of yet.

However, in terms of the combat system, visuals, loot system and level design, darksiders 2 is far better than the original (especially with 1080p in this version).
- Combat is much quicker than the original and gives you some options: 2 skill trees, differing secondary weapons, item stats etc. which is really awesome compared to the more linear progression in the first game.
- Boss battles are less frustrating while still being challenging and equally epic. This was welcome after the nightmare ♥♥♥♥-fest that was Stygian ;-;
- Visuals are the big thing in this re-work of the game. Originally they were 720p (I think bc it was made for last gen consoles, then ported over) however now they are 1080p and the game has had many other visual elements (animations especially) improved.
- Loot is done in a more traditional RPG style rather than the linear progression in darksiders. It's not /that/ great but certainly a welcome improvement.
- Performance is not an issue for me at max settings, (FX-6300 proc and R9 200 graphics). I only found a few glitches around the game, definately acceptable imo.

Note: A lot of negative reviews for this game centre around how Vigil and Gunfire screwed people over by inconsistant miss-management for providing discounts for deathinitive if people already had Darksiders 2, which meant many people who already owned darksiders 2 ended up paying full price for the same game with updated graphics. That was ♥♥♥♥. The game itself is awesome.

reviewText:
A solid game with a Zelda-like overworld/dungeon structure to it. Doesn't deviate much from the first Darksiders apart from adding loot drops and the added layer of character customization that such a system would bring. If you haven't yet played Darksiders II, this is a definite buy. Just an overall fun game that may not do anything new, but delivers a very enjoyable experience that very few can dislike. It's a very gamey game, and a good one at that.

Unless you're really jonesing to play it one more time, it may not add enough for people who have already played through the regular Darksiders II. It's noticeably better looking and the folks at Nordic did a respectable job of modernizing its visuals, but beyond that it's still the same game. See for yourself if it's worth it.

Many of the negative reviews surrounding the game are a result of the way its developer handled the way it gave loyalty bonuses to previous owners of DSII. I didn't have any issues buying this edition as I didn't own any of the DLC. Those who did own all content for the original game but bought it piecemeal rather than in the Bundle were upset they didn't get the game for free like those who did the latter. Could've been handled better, but in the end it's small fee for the fans, especially if you'd like to see a Darksiders III.

The game does carry over some of the bugs of the original, unfortunately, and doesn't appear to be well optimized to run on a broad range of machines, but the developer has been doing an admirable job of pushing out updates since its launch a couple of days ago to address the game's issues. I personally don't have any performance issues, but I've got a somewhat beefy system so I can't really comment too much on this.

reviewText:
tl;dr:  if you haven't played Darksiders II, if you dig hack-and-slash, if you like games that tell big stories and if you don't mind your games to be a little... glitchy then I'd say go for it.  I highly doubt you'll be disappointed, especially when it's on sale.  If you already own it, there's nothing new here (save for an even higher difficulty setting) that warrants another purchase but it does look nicer than before.

Pros:
Fun hack n' slash
Great voice acting
The artwork
Engrossing storyline
The Kingdom of the Dead (I would pay serious $$$ for another extended adventure there, and even more if it got brought to the Oculus or the Vive)
Post-apocalyptic Earth
Dat soundtrack by Jesper KydCons
Glitchy
KB/Mouse controls not always clearly depicted in interface
Enemies have predictable patterns
Later stages of the game are shorter, giving it a rushed feeling
A little heavy on the fetch quests
What, you want more?  Okay then, but know that there's no possible way I can be objective about this game.  I've put over 150 hours into the original.  I loved it so much, I was happy to buy it again when Nordic released the Deathinitive edition.  I even bought the soundtrack.  On CD.  From Amazon.  Because that was the only place I could pay for it at the time.  Yeah, it was that bad.

See, I loved the art, the world and especially the STORY of the original Darksiders so when the sequel was announced, I was eager to get my hands on it and eager to see what would be done with Death.  Darksiders II brought everything I wanted and a whole lot more.  Where Darksiders I was pretty straightforward hack and slash, Darksiders II brings a richer, deeper world that invited exploration and a more meandering playthrough.  Where power was gained strictly through item collection in Darksiders, Darksiders II brought a bit of a role-playing element in with character levels and a reworked loot and ability system.  And where War was a straight-up Determinator[tvtropes.org], Death is a more complicated character, with a wry-sense of humor delivered with pitch-perfect gravelly voice acting.  For me, the art, the monumental soundtrack (so good I need to hit it twice in this review), the cinematic set pieces and the sweeping plot arc of the story all added up to a game that was much, much greater than the sum of its parts.  Little wonder I've spent more than a solid week's worth of time playing it.

I'm sure I'm coming off as more than a bit of a fanboy here, and it's a fair cop.  I'm also sure that the Darksiders franchise isn't everyone's cup of tea and I won't begrudge anyone their preferences on that front.  But that said, and just for the record, if Nordic decides to get the band back together and make another sequel, I'm there.  Buying the Collector's edition.  Even if I don't know how they plan to top Death's story with Strife or Fury.  Don't care.  Hell, if I lived near the dev team I'd probably bring them coffee and pizza or other reasonably-priced alternatives in my free time.  You can practically hear me squeeing with glee at the very idea of it now.

reviewText:
Alright, about 42 hours of gameplay, having completed the game once on deathinitive difficulty, here's what i think so far.
This game starts off great
- It has some nice puzzles, that would occasionally stop me in my tracks and and consider looking up a walkthrough, but was definitely beatable without one.
- Combat feels nice, it is definitely an improvement from the last game. they have removed the blocking all together, and opted for dodging, which i can fully understand, as it was never obious as to what could be blocked and what couldn't. At times the game felt like it was just throwing more and more enemies at you to try and make it harder, but mastering dodging and fighting system it ended up feeling like it wasn't just being unfair but that i simply just weren't familiar enough with it at the time.
- The game is very visually appealing and runs fairly well. getting about 70 to 90 fps, with maxed shadow quality and no antialiasing, on a 970 running a 1440p screen, which is reasonable compared to other games.
- The only issue i have is that tabbing out can do one of three things, 1. Nothing. 2. Break sounds making only some sounds play and the rest of the time leave you in silence. 3. Crash the game. i'd recommend either playing the game in windowed, or downloading the Windowed borderless gaming" app
date: since the game does not support borderless windowed on its own.\n- The game has a random loot drop system which i don't feel the game needs at all. It scaled weirdly and doesn't give you much freedom. For the most part it's just: sell your old junk at the vendor and then buy the item with the highest damage or highest defense. reviewText:
There's plenty of people who're upset about paying $6.00 for an upgrade. Don't mind them, the internet always reacts in extremes. It's a game worthy of praise.

It's worth it to experience a great game with updated visuals.
It's worth it to have this version of the game which currently HAS developer support.
It's worth it to shell out $6 because the publisher will see that and be more likely to fund a sequel.

Gameplay feels just as smooth as it did in the original incarnation with Death traversing environments effortlessly, creatively comboing his enemies to death, and so forth. The direction of the art revision has held true to the original Madureira aesthetic as well - there's little deviation on the updated textures and color maps seem to have more of a visual pop thanks to the engine updates.

Look, here's the skinny: If you had it before and have the option of paying $6, just go ahead and do it. You pay more than that a MONTH for Netflix. :P

If this is your first foray into the Darksiders world, get the first game and use that to decide if you want the sequel.

Trust me, it's a good game and upgrade and worth a little green.

reviewText:
I've never played Darksiders 1 or 2 before, so this is written from the perspective of someone brand new to both the game and the franchise. It's a very fun ARPG, overall. Movement and combat are both fluid, the story is decent at worst, and maybe even good at best. Some specific points, in no particular order, follow:

1. Platforming is easy. You cannot 'miss' jumps, because Death (whom you play) grabs onto handholds and bars automatically, as long as you jump in that general direction. The platforming elements are more of a simple 'puzzle' than an exercise in virtual agility. As somone who sucks at platformers, I loved this aspect.

2. Puzzles are easy. Most of the time the solutions are obvious as long as you explore the surroundings. They're pretty inventive in certain ways, and each puzzle builds on elements used in the last one. As someone who sucks at puzzle games, I enjoyed them.

3. My combos get interrupted when I'm hit. I can see enemies pulling back to strike, but I haven't discovered a method for blocking or interrupting them, no way to continue my combo without either getting hit or rolling away, and starting over. Perhaps there is a way I've not discovered yet, but this is a slight annoyance to me. Only a minor one though.

4. Combat is very fluid and fun - comparisons to God of War come to mind (albeit without the long range of Kratos' chainblades, alas).

5. The game runs smoothly, and loads quickly, with hardly any loading screens at all once you've loaded your savegame from the main menu.

6. It's gorgeous! Sure, it's not gonna win any awards, but I find the game very good looking.

reviewText:
A fairly good game, IF you can get it to run right. Strangely enough, this version seems to crash far more often than its' predecessors, such as the original DS II. It is rare to play for an hour or two straight without a crash; thankfully, the autosave saves to a near obnoxious frequency, so I never really lost any progress. Nevertheless, crashing in any game to the extent here is extremely irritating.
Aside from the bugs, though, the game is fairly decent. The combat system is good, and there are a decent amount of sidequests and optional dungeons to complete. Unfortunately, despite having a semi-open world, there isn't much to do. The game is pretty much dungeon after dungeon after dungeon. Still, if you like hack & slash games, you will probably like this.

tl;dr
LOTS of bugs & crashes
Decent game otherwise
If you want to play it, you would be better off buying the console version.

reviewText:
In the previous game you played as the Horseman War. This time around you play as Death, one of the remaining three riders of the Apocalypse and, parallel to the events of the first game, you will do your best to find a way to absolve War of his supposed crimes.

Darksiders II offers similar gameplay as its predecessor at its core. However, this time around the designers and developers wanted to go bigger and a bit more complex. As a result, the game offers a much larger world, RPG-like character progression with skill trees and an RPG-like inventory system. Apart from Death's main mission, you will get a chance to solve a few sidequests as well and reap some additional rewards from them too.

The action is still as fun as it was in the first Darksiders and Death has some pretty nice moves himself. It's just a shame the spectacular gory finishers aren't as present in this game as they were in the first, but are tied to a specific weapon stat.

Even though the composer is different, the music is still excellent, handled this time around by Jesper Kyd - a name people who played most of the Hitman games and the first two Assassin's Creed games might recognize.

While Darksiders II is still a very good action adventure game, if I had to pick which of the two I enjoyed more, I would have to go with the first Darksiders. Most of the flaws that affect this choice aren't that big, but put together they result in a slightly worse impression for me.

This game does offer a larger world, but the switch from a ruined, post-apocalyptic Earth to four completely different worlds as the main setting also caused it to lose some of its charm. The bigger issue, in fact, is that looking at each of these four larger distinct worlds individually - their subsections are not as interesting, detailed and visually diverse as the various sections the first Darksiders offered in a single world. They also often feel as if they were made that big simply to justify the ability to ride your horse (you are a Horseman of the Apocalypse after all) and are rather empty as a result.

Several sidequests are tied to (a tediously high number of) various collectibles and are not that interesting. On the other hand, for a game that tries to go down the RPG lane, it offers too few sidequests for such a large open world - this contributes to that feeling that the world is a bit empty. In general, I feel that trying to add more RPG elements and going with a bigger world at any cost didn't do Darksiders that many favors (as much as I love RPGs).

There are many other tiny nitpicks I could name, but I will skip them in favor of one big problem - bugs! The first Darksiders was quite polished (apart from the Steam achievement thing, which becomes a non-issue once you know about it). This game, however, has quite a few bugs. At random points after prolonged play the sound will stop working and will not go back to normal until you restart the game. Using the Steam overlay will cause the controls to stop responding at a random point and the game will act as if in a paused state, fixed only by going back to the main menu and reloading your save. The horseriding is a lot more clumsy and you may end up having to dismount to get unstuck. At rare occasions you may also end up stuck inside a wall, causing you to reload your save game.
These are just a few of the most annoying issues I encountered and I am really surprised they weren't addressed for the Deathinitive Edition.

Despite the amount of text I spent talking about the flaws of this game, I still highly recommend it, just not as highly as the first Darksiders game. Still, if you can get past the bugs and some other potential flaws, you will have quite a bit of fun with Darksiders II.

reviewText:
If you played Darksiders 2, there is no reason to not buy it for cheap as it's simply a DLC-Filled Edition with a small graphics overhaul. Performance is severely impacted but the core gameplay and action greatness is there.
By far one of the best games of the 2010's decade so far. I honestly see no point in fully reviewing Deathinitive as I will approach the original soon enough and the differences are so small that they don't deserve a second review. It's literally sharper textures and adding DLC.

Yes, you can carry your save game from the original, which is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome! Kuddos, Vigil and Nordic!

If you're wondering whether to grab this or the original from a key store, defo grab this if your PC isn't 2005 levels of weak, Deathinitive Edition of DS2 is one of the best Action RPG's made and surpasses the Dark Souls franchise, hardly will you feel ripped off by this unless you're a texture ♥♥♥♥♥ or not an ARPG fan (and even if you aren't, there are so many elements beyond the RPG formula that you may end loving the game anyway).

reviewText: It's serviceable, but you'd expect less bugs and graphical glitching than the original release, not more. reviewText:
Product received for free

Play. The. Original. Version.

If you have both like me (I got Deathinitive Edition for free at some point before I found time to play the original), you probably want to play plain old Darksiders 2 and NOT this version. Why?

First of all, the coding is BAD. The graphics are technically more detailed (though I felt the original has richer colours), but systems FAR better than mine still have serious issues with choppiness and screen tearing. If you have a super monster PC, it might run smooth, but for a game that's from 2012 you shouldn't need a monster of 2016.

Secondly, the camera is insane. In Darksiders 2 it's reasonable - you can just move the camera like you'd expect. In Deathinitive Edition, you have to hold down a button while using the stick to move it. It does not move freely during combat and always snaps back to Death, making jumping very difficult, which you do a lot in this game.

Thirdly, a lot of oddities exist in the controls in general. For example, often you have to jump away from one object to another, but in this version it Auto-Leans away to begin with without pressing anything, so you often accidentally send yourself flying into oblivion instead of at the object you wish to go to.

Great game. You just probably want to stick to the original version and only run this one if you want the steam cards.

Edit: I also just noticed you CAN'T buy the original version on steam now. That's horrifying. D: I'm so glad I had the original version to begin with, because Deathinitive Edition is -unplayable- for all the above reasons (seperately!) on my machine and while far from being a hardcore gaming rig I consider it a pretty powerful PC overall.

reviewText: Short and sweet - This game is awesome and if you have a half decent computer then you're gonna have a good time. I encountered no frame drops, no crashing (except the start up thing for the first day), and no stuttering of any kind. Stay away from the negative reviews most of them are either sporting Pentium II's or butthurt kids who have everything in life served to them on a silver platter.\n\nThis is one of those times where I'm so damn happy that I disregarded the negative reviews for this game and went for it, I actually didn't have any of the DLC so I was happy to pay just 6 dollars for the remastered game and all of the DLC. One thing I was discouraged about was when I first bought Deathintive IT WAS CRASHING at the startup screen, every damn time, BUT it was actually PATCHED the VERY NEXT DAY. I got so excited to play darksiders 2 again. From all the negative reviews I read I was expecting a horrid looking, stuttering, ♥♥♥♥ port of a game, but in the first few minutes of the game riding up on despair to the icey mountain cave thing I watched the crows fly out at me through the snow in a wonderous 60fps world, and started drooling all over my controller. ( I always use an xbox controller with these type of games, and it also fixed the sensitivity bug) So yeah the game looked and ran amazing so far. I was holding my breath though cuz you know, all the negative stuff I read, it was going to crash soon or drop frames in an area full of tree's or something, but the further into the game I got more and more satisfied that i hadn't jumped on the letshatenordic-cuztheygavemeadiscount train" I played this game non stop taking a couple breaks for sleep and whatnot
date: I had a great time. Hell I even waited until I finished the main story until I wrote this just to see if it did end up crashing from a game breaking bug or whatever reason. So now I'm left thinking that are these people tryna run this game on a system still using windows 98
recommended: sitting there not able to figure out for the life of them why the game they're playing isn't able to run on ultra at 60fps so they come to the conclusion that it must be the games fault (obviously) I mean my computers alright but its nothing special and I could play this start to finish without a single issue. Overall I would reccomend this to anyone

LIKE PRINCE OF PERSIA: run accross that wall there to get to that platform there, then jump to the bar sticking out of the wall, then run accross a bit more of the wall, jump off at the corner of the wall onto the wall it connects to and keep running a bit further to hit that platform.

LIKE PORTAL: open a portal here, and one over there. go through one to come out the other. use this to get to certain areas unreachable. also use this to solve puzzles. similar to portal 1 and 2.

LIKE DIABLO: kill enemies and pick up new weapons gear, cash, etc. level up and use skill points just like diablo.

upgrade weapons, abilities, etc. buy new comboes, and other upgrades, etc

game is pretty open, i wanna say it's open world.


PROS:
amazing graphics!
great story
upgrading system
battle system is great
visuals/scenery is cool looking
open world
secret areas with special items
boss fights
etc

CONS:
beat the entire game, no cons, no bugs, no glitches.

i rate this 9.9 out of 10         ;)

reviewText: I've only played this game for about thirty minutes, and I'd already recommend it 100%. I'm running an R9 280x and an FX 8350, and I've had absolutely no stuttering issues whatsover at max graphics settings in full HD. I've actually beat this game about four times on my xbox 360, and loved it so much that I had to get the Deathinitive Edition when it came out. The combat mechanics are easy to learn, but hardly simple. The movement (dodging, climbing, etc.) is very fluid and feels extremely responsive. The storyline is amazing, and the soundtrack is simply unrivaled. And now, you can play it in full HD with better textures and lighting! I couldn't recommend this game more. Hope this helps!

reviewText:
GAME IS RUNNING FINE, THEY FIXED THE BUG! I AM PLAYING  ON MAX SETTINGS AND RESOLUTION WITH 60 FPS AND NO LAG OR STUTTERING.

To start off with, Darksiders 2 is quickly joining my list of favorite games of all time, which includes, Final Fantasy 7, Metroid Prime,and LOZ Link To The Past. Death is an awesome character and astonishingly badass with acrobatic moves, vicious attacks, and superb looking equipment. On top of all that, he gets to explore very creative and innovative worlds and dungeons that will lock you in and create one of the best atmosphere in all of gaming (In my Opinion) that will make an adult feel like a little kid again.

The gameplay is a blast (I played on apocalyptic difficulty). The enemy will force you to use all of your abilities which will require more than controller skills. Death's acrobatic dodge moves are very cool to watch and gets me psyched up every time I see them. His attacks are ferocious and exciting. There are tons of attack combos and moves to learn. Death will be equipping his scythe and a secondary weapon which can be a two handed hammer, fist weapon, Axe and more. The adversaries will use everything in their power to destroy Death but it will not be enough MWHAHAHA. The levels are filled with all kinds of obstacles. The puzzles can be a bit easy , but at the same time will make you think. Later in the game, it gets more exhilarating during boss fights. The bosses will make you think fast, quickly respond or they make you pay the price.

The environment and music makes this game even more fantastic. They scenes are beautiful and the wonderful music fits very well with the environment (I will be buying the soundtrack). The graphics remind me of much more mature World of Warcraft type style. Death will traverse all kinds of environments like water and fire styled dungeons. The dungeons are laid out in a Zelda type fashion, which suits my taste.

The story is pretty unique in its own way. You take the role of one of the four horseman trying to save his brother War. Without giving any spoilers away, I will just say this, Death may get side tracked with a much bigger problem.

With all that being said, this game is simply one of the best I have played. It has good mix from some of the best games ever made Prince of Persia, Zelda, God of War as well as staying unique in its own way. Great Job Vigil,

reviewText:
Gameplay
TBH I expected more combat, like in Devil May Cry. I'm disappointed it's actually more of a parkour Zelda, but that's nothing against the game. Hunting the chests is fun. The dungeons and puzzles are well designed so far. Scaling walls and mastering the climbing is rewarded.
I'm wary about backtracking. I hate intended backtracking. The world design lead me straight to an interesting dungeon I had no business attempting. It turns out the boss in there is an optional bounty, intended for characters lv6-12. I was barely level 2. I barely knew I or enemies _had_ levels yet. Yup. It's by the first cool merchant in the open world, and entices you with a chest. Why? Just block it off with an NPC or the hooks that already made me skip several chests.

Combat is fairly rewarding. Small groups of mooks are frequent and trivial, but that's expected. So far the boss fights have been neat and somewhat unique. As easy as it is to just mash light and heavy attack, encounters start to take some thought about dodge direction and how to utilize your active skills. So far most encounters are small and short. Maybe that will change. I'm not far.

This all said, it's fun and I probably will play it through. Secondary weapons seem to somewhat matter. Loot is cool. The demonic weapon upgrading is neat. The skill tree seems decent. I like you can respec, but it has a low-reasonable currency cost. Some old posts online imply you can actually have a 'build' by the end between the trees and gear. Not all solo ARPGs let you differentiate that much.

Graphics
I'm impressed. It looks and runs great. I like the art style a lot.
The first ice boss has a cool model and looked sharp. In game looks better than the video, more like the provided screenshots. I'm not experiencing the performance issues that generated most of the negative reviews. I assume they've been fixed. That said, I'm < 6hrs in as of this review.

Controls/Mechanics
Combat is smooth.
Lock-on could have been a toggle instead of a hold, but it's fine. I would have preferred trigger+button for assigned powers over bumber+button, but also fine.
As much as I love the look and idea of the horse, I wish they would have just given a sprint. The horse is allowed in very limited locations. Also, while I'm impressed they did seemingly pretty fluid mounted combat, it doesn't end up working. One hit knocks you off the horse, and unmounted (standard) combat is too far superior to be messing around on horseback anyway. I find myself moving through many areas wishing I could run faster, especially when retracing steps for a chest or to find/restart a climbing puzzle.

Climbing is generally impressively smooth.
Honestly, I expected ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t like missing beams or constantly jumping 90 degrees off of my intended jump angle. That's actually quite rare, and usually my fault when it does happen.
My only complaint here is when you can't jump onto or scale surfaces you definitely should be able to. Sometimes they're well under the standard jump height, with a gap in the walls/railing and everything. Just be aware there are well designed paths with generally obvious objects/textures, and you will be using them, even if it means going around or reconsidering dungeon rooms. Think more Drake's Fortune treasure puzzles, less Assassin's Creed.

This was a steal at $3. It's probably worth full price.

reviewText:
This is no Place for a Horse.
The final edition of Darksiders II with all DLCs and updates. Darksiders II is now obsolete. This is a great game, very entertaining, with beautiful graphics and great combat. If you have played Darksiders you know what to expect, but the experience is augmented in many ways. The world is huge and detailed, characters look and sound very nice.

PROS:
Graphics.
Improved over the original release.
Music\Sound\Voice acting.
Death.
World size.
Characters and art.
The story is catchy enough.
New game+

CONS:
Controller Mapping. You cant change it.
The black bars when you focus.
Some camera angles are terrible.
The game is not about combat at all.
The game is about puzzles, too many.
I found three game breaking bugs. Solved with Beta patch.
Would not replay this game, ever.
The only point in gearing is the last boss.
Last levels felt like a chore, too many puzzles.

MISC:
Install the Beta updates.

My score: 6/10

reviewText:
About half-way done through the game, and so far, it's absolutely wonderful. At first I was skeptical about getting this game after hearing that the Deathinitive Edition absolutely cucked this game up, but at a 90% discount, hardly room for arguing, and I'm glad that I did, and here's why:

WHAT'S GOOD ABOUT THIS GAME?    GAMEPLAY - Imagine Prince of Persia set in a relatively big world with exploration possible around every corner. Run on walls, solve little jump puzzles, fight tough mobs and sometimes groups of them, this plays almost exactly PoP. Familiar, yet with a personal twist.
CONTROLS/CAMERA - When you're running on walls, the camera almost never ♥♥♥♥s you over, unlike PoP. Enough to stand on it's own, to be honest.
STORY - The story is neat. Although I did not play the first game, you're given plenty of context in the beginning of the game and don't feel completely lost in what's happening. It's essentially a revenge story and you wanting to stop the Corruption.
BOSSES - Bosses - everywhere. All of them neatly designed and fun to find, fight, and beat. Unique and challenging, what more can you ask for?
SECRETS - Holy ♥♥♥♥♥ secrets everywhere, secrets within secrets, SUPER secrets! Find gnoMad's stuff stashed everywhere is loads of fun!
WHAT'S MEDIOCRE ABOUT THIS GAME?    VOICE ACTING/DIALOGUE - I found the dialogue and acting pretty cheesy. It fits the game, but I always roll my eyes when they start talking. Personal opinion though, so I won't count this against the game as a whole. Could be better, however.
GRAPHICS - Graphics are a bit dated for a game this relatively modern. My frames were good at max, but the textures and jagged graphics are irritating, since the game without them would be gorgeous with the large open spaces and nature.
DIFFICULTY - The hardest difficulty is pretty damn easy, and I'm usually not too good at these types of games when the difficulty is cranked up. What's up with that?
WHAT'S BAD ABOUT THIS GAME?    UPGRADES - This should really be in the mediocre section, but for a game that wants to feel like an RPG, the skill tree is, for the most part, useless. I rarely use any of the upgrades (except for maybe 2), so they fell a little flat here.
COMBAT - Related to the upgrades, combat is largely the same. I constantly use M2 over M1 over my abilities. There is never really a use for any of the abilities inside combat.
All in all, you can see that the game is not as bad as people made it out initially. If you are a fan of Prince of Persia and the likes, you should definitely consider checking this game out. If not, then it's a DEATHINITIVE sale purchase. Enjoy getting lost in a magical world as the horseman of death.

7.5/10

reviewText:
let me preface this review by saying that i *really* did not like darksiders. i thought it was badly designed, the dungeons and bosses were medicore at best and infuriating at worst and the controls were a nightmare to navigate, especially when anything needed to be manually targeted. because of this, i avoided DS2 like the plague, thinking it would be more of the same.

however, i was very pleasently surprised to find that darksiders 2 is far more tightly designed, open, and fun to play then it's predecessor. the RPG elements and loot systems are satisfying to engage with and tickles the part of the brain that likes to see the numbers go up. the dungeons are far better designed, with interesting puzzles and fun traversal sections that are clear, but just obfuscated enough to still be a puzzle. i never felt like the game was tricking me or like i was battling some badly implemented part of it like i was in DS1. even the voidwalker (see: portal gun) is far more interesting in DS2 then it was in DS1, where it felt gimmicky and tedious to use.

however, there are still elements that are less then ideal in DS2. without spoiling story beats, there are sections where the game becomes akin to a third-person shooter with an over-the-shoulder camera, which feels clunky even when everything is working well. the controls and gameplay systems simply aren't setup for this kind of play style, and the parts where these gameplay elements surface are very much weak links in the strong chain that makes up most of the play time.

the story and art design can be very hit or miss for a lot of people, but i found the goofy mismash of Every Mythology Ever sprinkled with more then a little bit of comic book logic was pretty entertaining, and Death is a pretty entertaining character. Joe Mad's art may sometimes look like a self-replicating WoW character that succumbs to greeble, but i feel like it fits the big, dumb world of darksiders.

i encountered a few crashing issues when alt-tabbing after the first world, which was strange, as well as a progression issue during the second DLC campaign in a side-dungeon, but nothing major. the touted graphical upgrade for the Deathinitive edition wasen't really noticable in a huge way, but it was very much welcome, though i wish the shadows were better, because they often fall prone to super bad striping in close-up character scenes. i played for 70 hours on a GTX 970 and a 3.4ghz i5 4670k with 8gb of ram at 1920x1200 and only had a few stutters when loading due to the game being installed on a mechnical external drive instead of my SSD

in conclusion, i was super happy to play this game and was ashamed for avoiding it for so long. sadly, we might never get a DS3 because this was very much THQ's swan song, but Nordic Games (who now owns the rights to darksiders) says it might happen someday. next time, i'll keep my eye on it.

reviewText: A very good game. Just purchased it during weekend for 3EUR, in 90%sale and it is absolutely worth the money. I haven't played Darksiders 1 nor the original Darksiders 2. I am completely new to the series.The game looks good on maxed out settings and runs smoothly. There was micro stuttering in the beginning, but googled on fix and implemented the first one,  which advised changing a parameter in nvidia control panel. this fixed the micro stuttering. Nice gameplay, it is not like you clear area and can forget about it. You gain abilities as you proceed further the story and thanks to these abilities you can revisit previous areas and access further parts of these areas, which were previously not accessible. Adds a kind of open-world feeling and makes the game less linear, or even non-linear. I am playing it on Normal difficulty and it is pretty challenging. You heavily depend from gear i believe...which is a drawback, but at least the game is challenging :) Started to pay it on Apocalyptic, but decreased the difficulty.

reviewText:
Im writting this after completing the game. It's pretty decent game now, though some bugs still remain but it can be finished without big problems.

+ It's playable without controller
+ decent fighting and mobility concept
+ Free DLC
+ Customizable weapons
+ Low requirements for decent graphic
+ rewards creativity

- Quite boring story mode
- No game changing options during game play
- Only 2 specs to play
-  Rather small maps


Definitely worth getting when on Sale. If we ever get DarkSiders 3 i recommend waiting until it's confirmed to be bug free and playable. They're pretty slow with fixing bugs.

reviewText:
If you want an overall review of the game it's all the way below.
I have played this game before on my xbox360, but then it keeps crashing. I absolutely love the combat and style of this game, it made the game epic and the awesome.

4 years later, here we go again..
I bought the darksiders franchise when it only costs me $5, and I was hooked to the game again. I remembered all of the action and gore in the game and whatsmore this is the definitive edition, which they called it DEATHinitive (pretty smart way to call it) The graphics are beautiful, everything looks more better and clearer, and I only have a Geforce 710m and an i5 core processor. The game got mixed reviews for the game back then mostly it was about the bugs but trust me I did not faced any bugs in the game and don't worry the game won't crash.

Graphics 8/10
Gameplay 9.5/10
Story 8.5/10

Bugs are fixed, game rarely crashes, it's a great game and you should definitely get it if you love RPG games.
Overall 9.6/10

reviewText:
i got this game on sale not really expecting much from it. all i can say is 'wow!'. i have been looking for a game of this ilk and play style for some time. this really doesn't disappoint. the story, well, it has one. to be honest i probably couldn't tell you it. however, i'm not much of a story guy. i've played some great story driven games in the past and the answer is much the same.
controls are so basic with basically near enough all you need on your mouse and movement buttons. yes, there some other buttons to press, but, you could almost get by using just the mouse and movement buttons by comboing them up. speaking of combos, fights have combos much like say streetfighter or mortal combat. it reminds me of the old classic games where they were so basic but still hugely entertaining. i 'really' enjoy this game.
control is responsive, graphics are above average, the story is more than adequate. a strong 8/10 for me, maybe even a 9.

tl,dr; basically when i finish the story i can definitely see me going back and trying hardmode. that, for me, is a massive compliment.
go buy it if you like sound of an early version of tomb raider with swords instead of guns and bows.
