reviewText:
Darksiders 2 Deathinitive Edition is the continuation of the hidden gem Darksiders: Wrath of War, after THQ went bankrupt, Nordic Games bought the franchise and re-released the game with all DLC’s included and improved graphics, maybe necessary or not, the fact is that many, including myself, want this franchise to get a third game, for the sake of the story and lore. I originally had the normal version of Darksiders 2 so I got this new edition for free.

Story
On this episode, we play as Death, War’s oldest brother, his mission is clear, to save his brother War of an unfair trial, blamed for the destruction of the Third Kingdom, because of this War has been imprisoned by the Charred Council. The storyline develops during the time Death’s brother is captive and whose soul is taken away as punishment. On this new adventure Death travels to many different worlds seeking the truth of what really happened on Earth and for this he meets new characters such as the Makers, who are old as creation itself, the crow father, keeper of secrets and many other demonic and angelic beings alike, some of them will stop you at any cost, some others will bargain to help you, whichever the case, Death’s path will be filled with powerful enemies, traps and many puzzles to solve, for in his journey he will have to face something more, Corruption has spread throughout the worlds hiding a more dangerous enemy well-known to the horseman, following the same formula as the original game, but this time with many more RPG elements and looting system, the search for the Well of Souls begins.

Gameplay
The game itself introduces a new system and mechanics, on the original game, the looting system did not exist, instead of that we collected artifacts and power ups that would help us gain more power. Now on DS2, a looting system has been created, a welcome addition if you ask me, as we struggle to get the perfect set of armor with many more capabilities and characteristics, we also have the addition of a whole new variety of weapons, scythes, hammers, axes, gauntlets and armblades, among others, which make the game much richer regarding content, we can also find possessed weapons, which can be upgraded by sacrificing other non-possessed weapons that will give them especial characteristics that will generate more damage, resistance or arcane abilities.

The worlds we travel through are bigger and filled with more puzzles that follow the same pattern as in the original DS, some of them are simply easier, and some others require especial tools to be solved with, which again will make you come and go from time to time to find unreachable chests or secrets that are far-off, all of this, enriched by the different worlds we will visit and enemies we will beat. Also, we count with a set of new skills and powers that will help us beat enemies easier and a level up system that will let us use much more powerful weapons and armor sets, always looking for a balance among them. Not great changes but still they are welcomed to get a better experience.

Graphics
When playing DS2 Deathinitive Edition I could not noticed the differences between the original version of 2012 and this new one, but as I got it for free, I thought I could give it a try expecting maybe the addition of the DLC’s in a different way (which I will address on another topic of this review) Nevertheless, the game still looks beautiful and follows the same comic-like patterns as the previous title, but this time it looks shinier and much more polished, and less rough around the edges, there are still some muddy textures here and there, but you forget about them instantly as you advanced on the storyline, considering the game has many different worlds, each of these worlds with diverse environments and vivid colors, from the more natural world of the Forge Lands to the gloomy and grim Kingdom of the Dead, the aesthetics of DS2 shows a variety in graphics, always highlighted by the details of every and unique world, beautiful art and design.

Music and Sound
The original Darksiders had a great soundtrack filled with more operatic and orchestral characteristics, here the music has changed, it was developed to what I believe a more atmospheric/ambient music, it really fits the game if we think about the world we visit, some of them require a different approach regarding the musical aesthetics, this makes travelling and dungeon/puzzle solving more appealing to the ear, it instantly hooks you to the mood of the mission, especially the Kingdom of the Dead, the music highlights the decadence of the kingdom and the gloomy atmosphere, the soundtrack has a lot of merit.

As for sound effects, they are equally good, you can feel the cracking of bones, the flesh being cut and scythes hacking and slashing the many enemies, demons still growl fearsome, angels still have that deep voice that make them feel righteous and fearless. As for the voice acting, I must say it is superb, on the occasion we have two famous actors doing voices, for Death we have Michael Wincott, who has done an outstanding job, it can’t be better, he fits the bill perfectly as for one the Makers, we have James Cosmo, broadly known for Game of Thrones and also the priest for one of the game’s trailers, just two actors to show how impressive the voice acting is here, they are believable and deliver powerful lines and flawless attitude for both characters. Just superb sounds and voices.

The Bad
When I got this edition of the game and heard that all DLC’s would be part of it, I was expecting for them to be included as major side quests, for the normal version of DS2 had the DLC’s as extra content, but outside the main maps we visit, but I was disappointed when I saw the same content was added the same way as before, it would have been much better to have these extra missions as part of the main story, making it easier and more comfortable to travel at any time during main missions, that is not the case and to do these extra quests, you must leave the main game and look for this extra content, a great addition but flawed by not being added differently.

As for technical issues, the game suffers from crashes from time to time, in the middle of battles or just randomly, annoying at times, but it doesn’t happen that often, what affects the game more I would say is the bug where every time you go to your map and come back to the main mission, every single key stops working, the only solution we have is to restart the game or just go back to the menu option screen and be lucky not to have it anymore, sometimes this helps sometimes it doesn’t, an annoyance when you want to continue playing.

Also, there are sound issues, when playing some sound effects and some voices will stop working, or sometimes all of them at the same time, I noticed that this happens when there are many sound effects working at the same, this produces some other to start malfunctioning or don’t emit any sound at all, again, restarting the game will solve this problem for some time, not knowing of course it will happen again anytime soon. For a deathinitive edition this is not game breaking at all, but it weakens the definition they use for a game that has been re-released.

Conclusion
As stated on my DS review, the franchise has been compared to other similar games that dominate this genre and what not, but I insist that DS has the lore and world to make a greater franchise of its own, they have the tools, they have a rich world full of factions, characters to make of Darksiders 3 the game we have been waiting for since Nordic Games bought the series.

reviewText:
TL:DR 7/10, beware it crashes a lot, but still very playable.


While the story of this game is seemingly written by a 15 year old who spends most of thier time in Hot Topic, the gameplay falls somewhere between action RPG with sometimes difficult puzzles.  The combat will feel very basic, as most of it will be just smashing the attack, but as you get into the late game you will need to start thinking a little bit more, but nothing a few well timed dodge and pokes, then pressing the 'execute' key when you're prompt to win the battle.  There is a glaring issue with the game on PC as it will often crash at almost random times, generally after a specific input from the player.  I often found that firing my ranged weapon or closing a menu caused the game to freeze and required it to be forced to be closed. The game does auto save EXTREMELY frequently, enough that the crashes never caused me to have to replay more than 30 seconds of gameplay.

reviewText:
I have a hard time reviewing this game fairly because of a contradiction. I like the game a lot and if you like ARPG games you will too. The problem is that the Deathinitive Edition is unstable and buggy. The crashing is particularly accute during NG+ (new game plus is a mode where you get to play through the game a second time w/ all your gear and skills carried over from your first playthrough) due to a bug having to do w/ displaying critical hit damage (details here). The good news is that the auto-save feature of the game works well enough that when it crashes you don't lose a lot of progress, w/ one exception, the Cruciable. The Cruciable is a special quest where you fight wave after wave (up to 100 waves) of enemies. This can be difficult to complete due to the unstable nature of the game.

I'm going to recommend buying this game but only if it's on sale for 75% or more because at those prices instability be damned it's a great buy. Just make sure you opt in to the beta so that you'll receive one game breaking fix and hopefully future updates that will address all the instability issues.

[UPDATE] You can significantly reduce the probability of a crash by turning off the damage counter in the Options menu. But it will not stop all crashes, just the major cause.

reviewText: Don't get me wrong... the hack and slash and RPG elements of this game are excellent. But why so many puzzles? The premise is simply idiotic -- why would angels and demons devise puzzles anyway? Wooden stumps protruding of massive stone walls? Pressure plates -- in heaven? In Darksiders it was something you could live with, but this time it was wildly overplayed, and manages to make an otherwise fluent and pleasant gaming experience plainly obnoxious. A game about the Grim Reaper slaying things shouldn't feel like Portal or Talos Principle. Worst of all, it hates being alt-tabbed, so if you try looking for a guide or a youtube video when stuck (or simply because you don't want to waste hours of your life on that nonsense), you might lose a good bit of progress on account of it crashing.\n\nOverall, a potentially great title ruined by lame and misplaced puzzles.

reviewText:
An excellent remaster that fixes what many users complained about when the original launched: HD textures, a different lighting engine (which may be subject to preference, as it is more realistic than before and thus things aren't as glowy anymore), DLC integrated into the main game, and plenty of fixes as well as rebalancing of enemies and gear.
Honestly, this upgrade is worth it for the highly detailed textures and new environmental effects alone.

If you've never played Darksiders II, this version is excellent for you, too. It includes all DLC content previously available and runs smooth on modern systems - even on my old (and hopefully soon to be replaced) AMD5750 graphics card, it runs just about the same as the original did, at a drastic increase in visual fidelity.

Overall, I am very pleased. Finally the game looks like the artists intended it to originally, but weren't able to realize before. It is well worth picking up.

reviewText:
Welp, figure I'd do a review of this despite it getting a good amount of backlash ATM. Now I'll be honest in this review since I'm judging the GAME and not the business practices the devs have pulled here, although those should be addressed. Check the negative reviews if you want to understand why, but given time they will be irrelevant since this version officially replaces the base varsion of Darksiders II.

I should also note my time spent is irrelevant because I have played and beaten both games multiple times back in my console days on the Xbox 360. Good? Good.

Pros: +An awesome story with an ever expanding universe full of well written and designed characters. It has humor, drama, suspense, horror, and even some well done sad moments.

+A visually stunning world. While the texture quality may be hit or miss given the year it came out, the game has an absolutely gorgeous esthetic that fits right at home with some of the best stylized games such as Borderlands, and many of Blizzard's titles. The colors are breathtaking and the character designs are somthing out of a good comic book, like Todd McFarland's Spawn" for instance.

+A sweet soundtrack with excellent visual feedback all around for this game. Everything from the combat
recommended: to the music ques oozes with ear warming sounds and makes the game feel even more satisfying to play. Audio is important to a title and this game passes with flying colors.\n\n+Fast paced
hoursPlayed: well done combat system with lots of combos and flashy moves to unlock
voteText: and tons of enemy variety with some seriously well done BOSS BATTLES that highlight just what a crazy universe this all takes place in.\n\n+Tons of content
helpfulPercent: especially with all the DLC now added into the game. You definently get your moneys worth with lots of varied locations
votesFunny:
and a thoroughly long and satisfying main quest line. Don't let my P.C time fool you.

+LOOOOOOOOOOT! If you are a fan of Diablo/Borderlands style loot drops with tons of weapons that game weird effects and make your guy look like a BAD-A$$ than you have come to the right game!

+Interesting Zelda/Metroid style puzzle solving that isn't too complicated but makes you feel smart anyway for completing it. Tons of secrets to explore too so watch out for that chest marker on the map!

+The Crucible. Normally I don't throw in things like this in a review as a bonus unless it's a seperate mode
commentsCount: but the WAVE BASED Crucible challenge is filled with great endgame content. It has awesome loot drops
column16: excellent challenge
column17: and some sweet extra boss battles outside of the main game.\n\n+ALL THE DLC!!!! I know I mentioned this when refering to the content for this game
column18: but it begs mentioning again. One of the biggest issues with DSII used to be how expensive and how numerous all the DLC was for new players. It even involved things that SHOULD have been in the base purchase like some of the dungeons
column19:
and the Crucible.

No game is without it's flaws and Darksiders II is no exception.

Con: -The port. Despite this being the "Deathinitive Edition" this game still suffers from poor optimisation
column21: and frequent framerate drops even when little is happening. I get it to work stable enough myself
column22: but if you are expecting 1440p 144mghz gameplay with a framerate that never drops with your two 980Ti's then you will sadly be disappointed.\n\n-Sometimes very frustrating puzzles and confusing level design. This doesn't happen often
column23: but I'll occasionally lost track of where I am going
column25: and what I am even supposed to do for the puzzle. I used to stumble into areas I wasn't meant to and run around wondering what in the world my crow buddy is trying to tell me... speaking of which.\n\n-The crow is freaking useless. He goes all over the place
column26: often in areas you just came from
column27:
and his pathfinding is the most confusing thing I have ever seen as quest markers go.

-Occasionally cheap shot enemies.

-Bad keyboard and mouse controls. I'm sure some people can get around this
column28: but I SERIOUSLY reccommend a controller for this game.\n\n-Barely any graphical improvement. While the game's style more than makes up for it
column29: the texture quality leaves a lot to be desired. Don't expect something like Witcher 3 from this. I can't stretch enough how good I think this game looks
column30: but that opinion is entirely subjective and some people simly wont like the style and the texture quality wont help support that feeling.\n\n-While the controls are fine overall
column31: sometimes the movement suffers from hectic combat and I cannot COUNT how many times Death has flipped RIGHT IN FRONT OF THE BIG GUY WITH A DRILL FOR AN ARM during his heavy attack and had half of his health nuked due to some dodgy... well
column32: dodge mechanics.\n\n-Annoying and sometimes cryptic Quest markers. Quest markers are CRUCIAL in an RPG and the ones in this game desperately needed to relay information better. They often don't give you much information in their descriptions
column33: and if it's designed for searching something it can be very frustrating due to the Zelda style level design. Sometimes they'll tell you to go somewhere and you'll be running around the quest marker hoping it'll move or give you a hint only for the objective to be under some underwater cave
column34:
in a secret room you have to find on your own. Combine this with Ash the Crow's crappy pathfinding and you will be left hunting the Darksiders Wiki for a lot of quests and puzzles.


Overall
column36: and this franchise as a whole. Now with a third entry in the series announced I simply cannot wait for this franchise to continue to grow and expand this awesome universe. I give Darksiders II a 9/10. What holds it back is some annoying Questing
column37: and subpar P.C performance. Many of the Base version's issues are solved with the DLC which boosts the score a point or two over the older version. It's worth every penny regardless and I am happy to reccommend this game even at full price. On a sale it's a complete steal."

reviewText:
Fun Zelda/God of War inspired game. Love the customizable weapon/armor and skill tree to make the gameplay style more interesting. The game had many issues before, but Nordic Games has been resolving some of the known bugs and game performances. Most of the negative reviews here are people who people complaining how this should be a free upgrade for original DS2 and how buggy this game was at released. I was glad to spend $6 bucks for the upgrade (although it's limited time only for people who owns original DS2 & free for people who owns the DLCs too if you contact costumer support), but glad to support an HD treatment with a possiblity of the making Darksider 3.

I deeply recommend this game because the developer's have been doing their best to please and keeping in touch with their costumer's issues, complaints and fixing all the known bugs/glitches.

#RESPECT

reviewText:
After playing the original 2 games many years ago on console I thought i would buy the franchise pack again on pc just because i love the series and hoped for a DS3.

Instead for now i have got a remaster of DS2 which i really wasn't expecting so i have decided to sit down and throw another 15 hours or so into this game to recapture what i have previously enjoyed.

If DS2 is fresh in ur memory getting this version might not be needed but for me I am pleasantly surprised with how much nicer this game now looks and the few little tweaks to balancing. I am not yet up to where the DLC kicks off but hopefully the integration into the game is smooth.

Pretty much if you enjoyed either of the Darksiders games picking this up seems like a no brainer for $6 on launch week.

This will fill the Darksiders hole i have been meaning to fill, hopefully till Nordic can make a 3rd installment.

All in all this is still some of the best hack slash loot action adventure rpg you can get.

reviewText:
I was very hesitant to buy this game because of all the negative reviews; but I did anyway because I missed this title a few years back and I've wanted to play it for awhile. So I bought the game for the $24 price. 5 minutes into the game it started glitching real bad and getting stuck in weird places (like the backdrop of the select screen of all places). I was super disappointed and nearly heartbroken. But then I switched the graphics settings to the highest available, and I haven't seen even one single glitch since that time.

Devs, if you're reading this, have this junked up game automatically start in the highest graphic settings...since evidently this is where its optimized to be.

As far as everything else goes, the graphics are beautiful. I absolutely love the scenery in this world, and the enemies are so different (mostly) from the ones in Darksiders 1. The game has ALOT more puzzles than DS1, and so far none of those pain in the ♥♥♥ shadow realm rooms. I'm enjoying it quite a bit, playing with my controller. I know there are alot of bad reviews out there for this game, but if you have a decent rig...and you've never played this game before...I DO recommend it.  Still in my opinion $30 is a bit much for a polished (albeit greatly polished) version of a 3 year old game, if you have your doubts...the steam holiday sale is right around the corner, and this game deserves a spot on the ol' wishlist.

reviewText:
Enjoyed the game, though I wonder how much my $6 really bought.

Graphics looked great, long story, and a quasi-open world feel.  Quite a few fetch quests but they fit will in the game and never felt like a chore.  Very nice array of boss monsters, each with their own tendancies.  Will take about 25-30 hours to complete the game.

Fighting mechanics are tight, or tight enough for me, but they need more controller options for the skills.  What I mean is that there are more skills available that the button mappings allow to use.  So, if you want to use a skill that is not mapped, you have to open a skill/item wheel and select it.  That takes away from the flow of the fight.

While the developers taught rebalanced loot, I found that there was a scythe and gauntlet that I received about half-way through the game that I preferred and had better stats than any of the loot, even loot of a higher level"
date:
that I found the rest of the way through the game.  There was a lot of throw-away loot.  Even possessed weapons didn't provide the stats necessary to take the place of my preferred weapons.

Only ran into a couple bugs - 1) An NPC got stuck in a wall.  Quit and came back in and he was free. 2) There was a cut scene where some of the dialogue and sound effects went missing.  Had to restart a few times before it straightened itself out.

The game also crashed one time
recommended: but only once and loaded right back up.\n\nAll in all
hoursPlayed: I really enjoy the Darksiders series
voteText: both I and II
helpfulPercent: and hope that the new owners of the franchise work towards a third game.\n"

reviewText:
Supposudly there was a crash issue on Day 1, but it's been fixed within a really quick window. So I can't hold it against the game.

As for a PROPER review.

This game is amazing. The characters and etc are created by Joe Madureira, a former cartoonist for Marvel. (It shows. Everything looks like it came right out of a comic.) The improved Graphics, textures, and lighting really help the game's comic book art style really stand out. (It's really great eye candy, and an example of a graphics update done right.)

The gameplay is unchanged from Darksiders 2, which is fine. Darksiders 2 is still a stand up when it comes to fantastic gameplay and level design. Though it is a bit lengthy, and some people can report growing tired around the third act.

I recommend this game a lot. Especially if you missed out the first time.

reviewText:
Hello guys, First I would like to start off by saying this is a very no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t review, so it may come off a bit blunt and left to some misunderstandings. I only played story mode and completed a lot of the sidequests and tried to get it fully completed, but you will read later why I didn't finish the game. I'm also writing this, because the other negative reviews are only downvoting for the sale, which is sad.
My first Impression

Beautiful, The landscape and the rest of the enviroment was beautiful, it was very easy on the eyes and the deathinitive edition complimented it. The tutorial was very cut and dry about everything and even gave you a bird to help guide you wherever you needed to go and even in later parts of the game as well. The characters all had charm, like you could feel their emotions and believe them. They were very good at explaining their surroundings and potrayed a certain history of it that makes it feel it had depth. The button combo fights were very fun and you are able to summon spooky ghouls to help aid you and the weapons system is like Diablo 3...except less complex, but still interesting. This game looked promising at the start and I wanted to play it for a while.

Now Here is the Cynical Review of it

Why does the world feel so empty? There is literally one area with nothing in it. It's so freaking huge, but there is nothing there. It only feels like I'm fighting 2 monster species in every area.  I swear there was only like 8 different monster species. Fighting the monsters at first are very satisfying, because you think, oh it's just the beginning, the fights aren't going to be too bad, but I better try to farm up and get better gear. Wrong. Dead wrong. Every monster you fight (Not including Bosses) feels exactly the same. A couple of autos and a super attack, that's it. Plus it makes the button combo fighting system feel very useless. Why do I need to use an AoE ability or a knockup? I could just easily press Square 3 times and kill them. It's not rewarding at all, AoE for example, You hardly every fight large groups of monsters in the game. There is no strategy or uniqeness.

Next topic, Run speed or Area clears.

I swear to god, I felt like I was in areas for half-hour to an hour, in some cases. All I would be doing is solving an easy puzzle, run back, fetch this, run around again, and so forth. I understand that the game environment is beautiful, If anything they did exceptionally well on,  it's how details that were put into like a statue or broken down stones, but for once, I wanted a Sprint system. Did I not mention how huge some of these dungeons are? I felt like I was running in Quicksand.

Quests...

Storyline aside, if you play this game, you will soon find out how redundant these quests get. There is even one of Main Quests that makes you do the same thing except different part of the story WTH? I feel like these tedious quests are just meant for you to run around and kill time. Paired with the uninsteresting monster fights it doesn't bode well at all.
Now I think the point of these tedious quests and big areas was the puzzle solving. For the first few hours, it was sort of fun to do and made me feel like a champ, but they really limited the puzzles to where it just feels like another chore. If this was the first game you ever played, then this doesn't really partain to you, but if you played God Of War, The Legend of Zelda, Prince of Persia. You know that this is really just another copycat that only offers a half-written story.

Storyline
So when you're first exposed to it after darksiders 1, It's interesting, because it's new and we like new things. Once you have acclimated to it, you start noticing things like why this, how, or this doesn't make sense. That's because there is only a partial bit of depth to get you where you're going. The plotline was Death needs to rescue his brother, but first he must fetch all this ♥♥♥♥ first, then he must solve these spooky puzzles, and after that you must defeat the ultimate evil.

I recommend that if you played games like Zelda, God Of War, or Prince of Persia to stay the hell away from this game and just watch the 2 hours worth of cutscenes on youtube rather than 20 hours of tedious, redundant, and non-unique gameplay. You're not missing anything by doing so which is why I said earlier that it has little depth and still understand that you can just do so. I didn't finish the game after 75% completion and just watched the rest and still made sense.

reviewText:
People have written many negative reviews due to issues when the game was first released.  Is it actually fair to do such a thing to cripple a game in that way when especially when there was a fix, posted on the forums and then then an offical patch to fix the issue with the game.

Also there is the issue that Is beyond people's control at this point.  and that's the discount vs gettng the game for free if you owned all the existing content for DS2.  I can understand that it makes people mad, but then again, not a reason to give the game a bad review.

So with this out of the way... On with the review.

What can I say about this updated an improved version of Darksiders 2.  Well one thing a lot of returning players will notice is the improved visual quality of the textures and the lighting.  and in a lot o cases, with the new lighting that has been added to the game it makes the game look complete different compared to the original.  Some might say that it is good, and some might say that it is bad.  to me, I am actually mixed about this,  seeing as how the new lighting can at times make it harder to pick out important parts of the terain that you need to move forward, such as ledges on walls etc.

What you also get with this version of the game is all the previously released DLC and weapons but unlike the previous version they have been seamlessly intergrated in to the game.  No longer do you get a whole bunch of weapons and armor, but instead you get these weapons and armor as the game progresses.  Also the extra DLC missions are unlocked as you progress through the story.  Which if you ask me is a much better and more thought out idea.  seeing as how you can't do some of the DLC without having equipment from the main game.  this makes the DLC more enjoyable when you go in to it with the tools that you need.

All and all I would say that this version is an good update to the original which had it's share of issues, and I will admit they still do exist in this version.  But hopefully now that Nordic games is activly working on the IP and the game itself a lot of these issues can be addressed and the game will finally be turned in to the game that we've all wanted for so long.

In the end.  if you're new to the games, both Darksiders and Darksiders 2,  I'd pick them both up,   They both are great games and tell a great story with lots of action.  If you're returning to the series after putting Darksiders 2 down for awhile.  I don't think that you will be disappointed by the visual upgrades and changes made to the game.

I dont make many reviews but this is a game i have to review, as a big fan of Darksider franchise i love the series, Now for this Deathinitive Edition its pretty much just a small upgrade from the original Darksiders 2, The game still plays exactly the same as the original DS2, Also haven't had any issues with this game at all, Except for day 1 issue with the shadow stuff but the Devs fixed it, And the Devs are trying hard to fix a few things that keep messing up, Its a great game and i loved it after playing 20hrs of this game with no issues i can say its well worth it

Don't listen to all the community negative reviews, over 98% of those reviews are just people who are angry cause they dint get the game free like so many other people, And Are people who dont even own the game and like to ♥♥♥♥ on things for no reason, so they are just hating this game because they have to pay and others dint, But overall the game is great love it and i am definitly hoping there is a DS3 in the future <3

TLDR: Great Game, Devs Active trying to few things, Not that big of an upgrade but you can see the differences in the 2 great game give it 8/10

reviewText:
It's good to see the developers come in and keep working on this title. What can I say? This is a great series and Darksiders 2 needed some extra love.

The visuals look even more stunning compared to when I first played this game on the PS3. The Deathinitive Edition comes with all the DLC I had missed out on, better visuals, and a few tweaks here n' there to improve the mechanics of the game.

That said, there are a few issues with this game. Let's be honest, the game shouldn't be graphically demanding - so why does the game dip lower than 60 fps when I have a decent rig equipped with a GTX 980? I guess I'll cut the devs some slack hoping that they are continuing to optimize the game,

The DLC is hard to access. Entering the Tome, there's NOTHING. No DLC weapons, nor a crucible ticket. Maybe I have to progress further into the game, but it would've been great to be briefed on the new changes so that returning players can know how to get themselves accustomed.

Is it worth playing again with this Deathinitive edition? Well, if you can get this game for $6 like I did - it's worth a shot.

reviewText:
I love this game. It runs flawlessly for me (GTX 980), which I'd expect given its age. Not sure how well it works on other hardware, so make sure to check other people's performance if you're concerned about your own setup being able to handle it.

It's a lot of fun, and looks as good as it's ever going to thanks to the polish it's received. Storyline might be confusing for some, but I'll try explain this as easily as I can while remaining conscious on this much Morphine: Nephilim are cross-dressers who like to get jiggy with dead bodies... Wait, no, wrong creeps, I was thinking of Aunt Robert - they were combinations of Angels and Demons. Because why not, right?  There were lots of them. They killed everything that moved.

The powers-that-be didn't like this and struck a deal with 4 such Neph: We'll give you supreme power if you f*** up anyone whose race starts with 'N' and ends with 'ephilim'. A few hours later, Death (who was known as Horace the Horrific at that point because of his Horrific taste in Halloween masks) cottoned on to what they meant, and he and his two Brothers, as well as his sister (called Fury, because... well, you know, 3000 years of PMS will do that to you, not to mention having 3 brothers who always leave the toilet seat up) decided to slaughter them all.

Stuff happened, more stuff happened after that, and then someone went and broke some Seals (the other Seals were so upset by this they all went Clubbing after the funeral)  which indicated the Apocalypse was meant to begin.

Except it wasn't, but that didn't stop War (known in some circles as 'Stoney Tony') from f***ing up big time and starting the Apocalypse accidentally himself. Oops. I told him to lay off the Pixie Dust, but would he listen? Would he f***.

With Humanity wiped out, Horace was all, Goddammit Tony I can't take you anywhere AND PUT THAT BLUNT OUT FOR KANYE'S SAKE"
date: so he then goes to try and reverse this catastrophic set of events
hoursPlayed: that and so he could get all stabby-slicey with the local demon populace.\n\nAnyway
voteText: long story short
helpfulPercent: this game rocks
votesTotal: it plays well now that it's fixed (devs fixed a catastrophic crash bug in 24 hours - hear that Rocksteady?) and the only complaints I know of right now are the fact that it doesn't run perfectly for everyone. Yeah
votesFunny: I know

column17: then I've got some bad news for you - Horace will be COMING FOR YOU. Or was it ON you? Actually
column19: that would be much worse.\n\nMy rating - 8/10"

reviewText:
HEAVILY EDITED POST PATCH

First up, I absolutely adore the original version of Darksiders 2, I can look past many of it's foibles and problems and would heartily recommend it to anyone with even a passing interest in this genre.

The main issues regarding the negative reviews ire twofold, firstly there was a crash that happens just after you select your save (or start a new one), click through the 'autosave' announcement, check your settings, then load, at this point the game crashed.  There is now a patch that has addressed this problem.
Secondly many negative reviewers are citing the pricing model as the main reason for the negative reviews.  While I can understand this can be infuriiating for some, that has NOTHING to do with the game itself.

On to the review...


The art style is fantastic, cartoony with just enough grit to make it feel different.
The texture work at the moment is spotty, with some fantastic and pretty high resolution/definition (for the game engine) model texturing but many of the world textures are still original, also including many of the weapons and armour you pick up during the course of the game.

The sound is flawlwss, as in the original, with all the grunts, slashes, and thumps you'd expect.  The voice acting is pretty good too, with certain voice actors hamming it up a little here and there.  The soundrtack is awesome, as before.

Unfortunately as of this moment, performance is woefull in placesl, a LOT worse than the original both at 30fps and 60fps there was a LOT of frame juddering, stops and starts, frame skips etc, the original ran a LOT smoother on my rig, although that may be down to the extra workload from the tweaked game engine.

After re-reviewing this game now I can actually play it I would reccomend it to those who can get it cheaply, and those who don't own the original.

reviewText:
This version of the game looks more realistic than the previous version. Patches have improved performance, which was garbage on release, however this still suffers from micro stuttering which requires a separate fix.

Unfortunately, the game loses a lot of its color and flashy effects which were some of the things that made the original game special. Whether you get this version or the original is up to you, if you want sharper textures and realism, this is your version, however it also washes out the high contrast lighting and colors from the original. This video shows a comparison between the old pc release, and the ps4 version of this one, and the PS4 version doesn't have very many differences to this one - and it's easy to see what I'm talking about: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=84LmGBqqPLs

It's up to you to decide which version you prefer, however I much prefer the look of the original version over this one. At this point, they are both playable versions of the game, I just wish I could take the textures from this and apply them to the older version.

reviewText:
Lets just start by saying that paying the 6$ that i had to fork up for this was the most frustrating thing about the game. However I refuse to factor the cost in my opinion of the game so if you can afford it...Read on...otherwise this review will serve you no purpose. All this being said, I want to support Nordic Gaming because I personally want another Darksiders game and really don't wish to see this project shut down.

In terms of the graphical updates such as the lighting and visuals, I'm impressed compared to what the older game was. Game looks sharp and crisp however by no means is it Division quality. But again thats a different game and based on what they had to work with this game looks really good. I also am enjoying the Deathinitive difficulty not being carried by possessed weapons throughout the entire game as they just ♥♥♥♥ out of chests in the older game. Either that or i'm just incredibly unlucky but I doubt that. Bosses actually feel like bosses and even certain trash mobs are incredibly difficult unless your reaction is on point.

Now lets talk about all the bad reviews (which were all posted day 1) about all the bugs and crashes and nonsense. Doesn't exist at all, atleast for me. There was even an issue with the aiming (last week) where it was maxed out on sensitivity making it near impossible to aim. Also gone now. It appears to me that Nordic Gaming is hearing our crys and is patching things together in a quick manner and with that being said, I feel I could trust them bringing justice to a new Darksiders title. I hope they keep up the good work and I'm interested to see what more they can do down the road.
voteText: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Firstly, I love DS and DS2 - they are a fantastic blend of exploration, puzzle solving and hitting things with MASSIVE weapons!

The Deathinitive Edition of DS2 is a tricker thing to rate - the visuals are improved and the DLC has been blended into the game better, but that comes with a performance penalty in a game which wasn't the best performing title at the best of times...

My PC could run DS2 at 60fps (mostly) if I disabled SSAO.  The Deathinitive Edition manages more like 45fps with the same settings - it's perfectly playable but it's not ideal.

Hopefully they'll iron-out some of the wrinkles with patches but it's not unplayable by any means and the core game remains excellent IF you have the horsepower to play it.

***Edit***

They seem to have fixed it with the 11.1MB update:

-hit the reset configuration option and it launched (manually blowing away the configs and removing steam sync did NOT work for me)
-changed settings to - 1080p, Vsync on, max AA, medium shadows, Ambient Occlusion on, restarted the game, looks great!

It does look better at 'max' settings vs the standard edition, not mindblowingly so, but it is marginally better; textures are a bit better, especially on the 'main' characters, AA seems to smooth much better (evergreen trees still look pretty bad lol)

reviewText:
This is the first time I actually write a negative review.
The reason is the camera stuttering which has also been reported by many other players. - which makes it impossible to enjoy the game. I have yet to witness similar problems with other games - It's like the camera is getting stuck and then suddenly moves to a new position, while the rest of the game appears to run smooth.
I'm quite sure that my PC isn't the reason for this since it can run similar games just fine.

I know that other players recommended  getting the beta patch. - So I did, but unfortunately this did not fix the problem. Neither did playing with the options. I really tried to fix the problem, following the instructions on the forum, but nothing helped.

I would have loved to play the game, but with that weird camera movement it's just impossible.
It's a mystery tho since there seem to be many people who do not experience the issues mentioned above.
If it was an option, I would give this game a neutral rating, since not everyone seems to encounter the camera stuttering.

So, please forgive me, fans of darksiders II, but for me this is a clear Nope. Going for a refund.

reviewText:
Now That I am a good 10 hours into this, I will just have to say it handles better than the original, the Items you had as DLC in the previous version is integrated into the game, it reminds me of what was done to Sleeping dogs.. My frame rate is at a Constant 60fps and the combat is still awesome and quite a few things have changed in the overworlds I have visited so far like foliage and textures.. granted this was before I got the beta patch. Where the only thing I would have complained about was the aim camera going nuts when i try to aim at something (Thanks for fixing this Dev)... its since fixed and the game works perfectly.

Initial Score: 8/10
Buy it and have a grand journey (again if you have played it before)

Ok Now that i finished it, I can add my full experience. There are still very minor bugs and one even helped me finish the game with a over upgraded possesed weapon but not to the point of game breaking, and perhaps a crash if you had a long session. the visuals have definately changed from the Darksiders II version i got to play at a friends house and even he is consideing getting this version because of it, I still had constant 60FPS throughout not even a frame drop when there were many enemies..

Final Score: 9.1/10
Definately buy it, the dev team have been great in addressing the bugs and I am sure it will be perfect soon enough. and I am currently on the New Game+ Run on Deathinitive Difficulty.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Darksiders II is a great game in itself. The combat is fun, the puzzles are well put together. Getting loot is satisfying, and feeding junk to possessed weapons at least feels like you are accomplishing something.
The visuals are nice to look at, and the game can run smoothly even on a bit older hardware, as the game underneath is not exactly next gen. Deathinitive edition finally brought everything up to HD.
Game is fully playable with both keyboard and a controller, after a fix to aim mode that came up like a week ago.
Dethinitive edition adds all the DLC to the package.

The only downside to the game would be the story. While there is always something going on, it rarely makes too much sense until you dig into the lore.

I'd give it a 9/10.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hVDo9vsfzjY

Please note that I played Darksiders 2 in it's entirely when it came out on Xbox 360, the time I spent with this version was meant for me to get a look at the remastering job.

Darksiders 2 Deathfinitive Edition is perhaps the best or maybe the worst subtitle to ever grace a video game. Nordic Games, who purchased the IP from the now defunct THQ, may have chose this name ironically, making fun of the plethora of remasters that have graced this generation, or maybe they actually thought it was a good name making this more of a tragedy than a comedy. I’ll be honest, what you’ll get out of the Deathfinitive is largely dependent on whether or not you’ve played Darksiders 2 before. The remastering job done by Gunfire Games is commendable, however, they touched up a game that arguably didn’t need touching up. The great setting, over-the-top story, and intuitive combat are still present however, and if this is your first experience playing Darksiders 2 this is currently the best version to pick up.

Darksiders 2 has a distinct visual aesthetic that is the result of the original developers, Vigil Games, hiring a comic book artist as the art director. This produced a larger-than-life dark fantasy theme that gives the characters, world, and combat a very unique look. Because of the stylized graphics Darksiders and Darksiders 2 have aged very well; if the art style had been more realistic and grounded this could be a different story, however, the remaster job here almost goes to waste as a result. I have to be honest, I had to do a direct comparison in order to see a difference between the two. While the lighting has certainly been enhanced and textures are sharper, the overall aesthetic of the game is still exactly the same, enhanced by the visual upgrade, but by no means creating a new experience. In short, the Xbox 360 and Playstation 3 versions of this game still looks fantastic and getting the Deathfinitive Edition for just the graphical upgrade may not be the best idea.

But maybe you haven’t played Darksiders 2 and you are looking to give it shot? That’s great because, in my opinion, this one of the best original franchises to come out of last generation and Darksiders 2 is the better of the two games. The series is famous for its derivative nature, taking elements from other franchises then combining them and twisting them into something unique and often time successful. The combat is typical combo-driven hack and slash fare similar to God of War or Devil May Cry. You do upgrade your abilities through an RPG mechanic that has you putting points into either offensive or defensive abilities depending on your play style. There is also a loot system that feels half-baked and unnecessary; it really just becomes a game of making sure you have the best armor or weapons equipped rather than strategically picking the right item for the right situation and it’s probably the only real issue I have with the game. The previous game had you focusing more on upgrading existing equipment rather than constantly picking up new items that drop from fallen enemies and chests. The world is structured similarly to a Legend of Zelda game where you have a large hub world with smaller dungeon areas branching off from it. In order access new areas you must acquire new gear and it always feels like you are progressing. All in all the gameplay loop is satisfying and keeps you entertained for the 20 or so hours it takes to complete the game. Combine that with a fairly standard yet entertaining dark fantasy story, memorable and well voiced characters, and an appropriately epic soundtrack and you have the making of a terrifically entertaining experience that is well worth your time.

It is difficult to review a remaster especially one for a game that only came out 3 years ago. The work that went into remastering this game is commendable, but ultimately wasted when you directly compare it to the previous versions. And while it is nice to get a Darksiders game on the current gen consoles, the experience feels some what incomplete without the first game. You won’t be totally lost diving into Darksiders 2 first, but there are references made to characters and events that may make newcomers wonder what they missed by not first playing the original. And there is almost nothing here for seasoned fans of the series. Nordic Games has been honest stating that they are releasing this game to gauge interest in a sequel, but I wish they had done more to entice the old audience to re-purchase the game. Including the first game or making a worthy collector’s edition would have gone a long way, but as it stands Darksiders 2 Deathfinitive Edition is a bare-minimum effort that really only makes sense for newcomers or the most die-hard fans looking to support the franchise in anyway possible. All in all Darksiders 2 is a fantastic game on its own and this version does nothing to diminish what I believe to be one of last generation’s hidden gems.

reviewText:
Note: Review for original DS2 plus my take on Deathinitive at the end.

Darksiders II will go down as one of my favorite games of all time.

I really enjoyed DS1 and was eager to see what DS2 had in store, although I was a bit nervous at first about playing as Death instead of War. I got over it.

First, DS2 compared to DS1:
Much larger world with more characters to interact with.
Tons of new weapons, armor and powers to mix and match to your play style. Feels almost like an MMO!
Use your horse from the get-go.
Where War is heavy and powerful, Death is nimble and lithe.
Minor notes: There's no double jump or underwater attacking.
Second, DS2 as its own game:
Pros:
Nice graphics, architecture and atmosphere.
Soundtrack is pretty cool.
Very fluid and intuitive gameplay. There are tons of combos or buy/learn and lots of weapons to try out. Whether your style is magic, heavy hitting or quick attacks, there are weapons and powers for everyone.
It's got a bit more parkour than the last one, which is fun. If you've played Prince of Persia (2008) it will seem really familiar.
Story is lengthy, but a little convoluted at times. The DLC/bonus campaigns are a nice touch.
Boss fights are good and I liked the puzzles.
Lots of sidequests.
Cons:
Some missions become a little too fetchy." I need to talk to person A. Person A won't talk to me until I get items X
date: Y and Z. I get X until I collect α
recommended: β and γ. You get the idea.\nSometimes I forget why I'm doing what I'm doing.\nSpoiler:  You never interact with War
hoursPlayed: although it is your mission to save him.\nTowards the end of the game
voteText:
it got a little buggy: More on that later.
Gore/violence is not that much considering it's "M" rating. I was expecting more severed limbs and guts.
Deathinitive Edition:

I was in a weird position. I was actually about halfway done with the standard edition of the game when the Deathinitive came out

reviewText:
Darksiders is one of the best games I've ever played. It has a nice and entertaining stoty (A long one) which I enjoy in games. A lot of games nowadays just care about Multiplayer experience but this kind of games are worth it.
I've found some issues in the game, minor but they're there.

1- Still suffering of frame drops. I have 16GB RAM, AMD FX-6300 and NVIDIA 750Ti (2GB) and the game asks for 512MB so, that means the game isn't really optimized for high end graphic cards (A problem that a lot of old games have) but they're in some areas, like big places but, it is ok
2-Its controls are designed for Xbox/PS so, using a keyboard will be a bit of a struggle. I'm used to it because I played Darksiders 1 in PC too but if you haven't, make sure you spend some time getting used to them
3- Another problem with controls, while in the tutorial, you get some control pop-ups (Like press W/A/S/D to move) but, I noticed that there's a mistake (At least it happened to me). The mistake I found was Press CAPS to jump off the ledge" but it is actually SHIFT+SPACE.

That's basically all the problems I've encountered. I know I have less than 1 hour gameplay but I finished Darksiders 2 before it became Deathinitive edition and I actually have both in my steam library. If you can
date: buy the Darksiders Franchise Pack 2015. I highly recommend that you play Darksiders 1 before playing Darksiders 2 as it is important to understand the story of the game itself. If you find any grammar mistakes in there I'm sorry
recommended: not a native english speaker lol."

Pro:

- New difficulty and game was rebalanced
- It's nice to have a cheap version of the game that includes all DLC

Cons:

- Shadows look like ♥♥♥♥, even though I'm playing on highest settings
- Random fps drops and input lag, even though I can easily hit 120+ fps with my setup
- I'm not sure what it is exactly, but 1440p doesn't look like 1440p

To sum it up, the developers are lying when they say:
Improved Graphic Render Engine for higher visual quality especially in terms of lighting and shadows
Improved and reworked level
date: character and environment graphics"\n\nIf you like playing optimized games that are not simply bad console ports
recommended: don't buy this. If you like console-quality

reviewText:
*Edited Review*

So after searching around the posts I found a workaround to the game crashing thanks to someone figuring out what seems to be the cause. If you delete the option files in two places it stops the crashes as it seems having shadows set to anything other than low will just crash the game.

I've been playing for a few hours now and love the update. It just looks far and away much better than the first release. While some complained of the lack of color and the darker lighting, I like it quite a bit. Everything feels less washed out than it did. Plus the up-res in textures as well as the updates in some just really helps make this game look great. Along with of course the 1080p, which I got working though I know some did not.

Weapons and the like do seem to be a bit more well rounded. I haven't come across the DLC weapons though I believe they are scattered throughout the game now instead of just getting them at the beginning.

Overall I'm having a fun time playing through the game yet again as it's been awile. Hopefully I won't come across anymore bugs!

___________________________________________________________________________________
*First Review*

I was incredibly excited to hear that I would be receiving this game for free! I love the Darksiders Franchise and they are my favorite games overall. Unfortunately however, I cannot even load a new game up before it just crashes. Consistently crashes as well no matter what. I do have an Xbox controller hooked up so I will see if unplugging it helps.

I really want to play this game and give it an awesome review!

*Edit - Unfortunately unplugging the controller does nothing. It crashes after I start a new game and the logo comes up. Right as the first tip comes up for dodge rolling, it crashes.*

reviewText:
Darksider 2 is that kind of games that transport you to an epic adventure where do you not expected, the music and the combat system is beautiful making every moment so fun. Since the first darksiders you dont expect much of this game except for the story to continue about the other horseman, but when you played it seems like a different game with a lot of improvements. The combat system is so dynamic and included more rpg elements, you have two different trees of skills and different equipment for death, the story is sublime and never get repetitive.

Now about this edition you probably read other reviews about complains of the free upgrade for the franchise pack users (blah..blahh) for me was free XD. The game really look renew and with a new face (new textures, effects and  a lot of more fun) i have not experienced any troubles in the performance, if you enjoy the first DS2 you must have this edition. The ultimative experience of deaths epic adventure".

Greetings

reviewText:
I absolutely recommend this excellent game. lets show our support and secure TWO more games in the series, the franchise deserves it.

reviewText:
First things first: I knew what I was getting into when I purchased this, and updating my base edition of DS2 with none of the DLC to the Deathinitive for six bucks was a great deal. I was neither an early adopter nor had spent a great deal of money on the game beforehand even for the core version, so the update's price doesn't really bother me from a personal stance, though I can understand both early adopters' laments and the issues Nordic is having to deal with considering the license transfer from THQ for the property.

So! Is it worth it?

As a DLC update, yes, though I have yet to see any of this DLC in the game (I've got closer to 10 hours in the game including time in the original DS2 as I was in the middle of my first playthrough when I saw the announcement for this.) As for everything else, the changes are either quite small or I simply haven't come across them in a major way yet. SOme models seem slightly tweaked, but nothing extreme, and overall anyone coming into this expecting a world of difference will be disappointed. DS2 is a great game, with solid controls, a beautiful world, and some of the absolute most amazing music I've ever heard, but it is by no means a groundbreaking title, serving as a mixed-bag of Prince of Persia, God of War, and Zelda and mixing the three into a tasty combination that works well but fails to do any one thing as well as its inspirations. The Deathinitive Edition is the same game but with more content, so don't expect it to change your mind if you weren't impressed by the regular version.
voteText: 11 of 24 people (46%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Look, Nordic Games are doing their best to provide us with a genuine, fun, new experience with Darksiders 2, so cut them a little slack. They new they were getting to into a pretty picky fanbase, and they're trying their best.

Now, onto the review:

The game is the same as Darksiders 2. If you were expecting Darksiders 3, I'm sorry, but this isn't it.

There has been some changes here and there, graphical changes, UI tweaks, texture rises, as in, the textures don't look like absolute ♥♥♥♥ now, general tweaks to enhance what THQ left us with. Now, are they bad, or good? Well, they're kinda both.

On my end, the V-sync is almost completely broken, as it was in the original. AA is also broken, as far as I can tell. I didn't pay too close of attention, though. I alt+tabbed once and the game crashed. Got me a little pissy, but I remembered this is an active thing, and fixes are coming/will come. So we're going to have wait and see.

Nordic Game hesitated on doing things with this because they know how we, the fan-base, can get if not done properly. I have been a loyal fan of the Darksiders series since day one. Loved War's story, and I love Death's story. I love the gameplay and art style of both, these games were a dream come true in my own opinion. The develops though, ehhh...

Darksiders 2 was broken to begin with, even without this new Dethinitive edition. And Nordic Games are trying to remedy that. They're doing their best, and at the moment, they're doing an okay job at that.

People need to learn to be a bit more patient, and wait for more fixes. You people gotta realize this came out in 2012, and they're just restarting updating it. It's gonna take some time before they get it into a stable condition, all along adding slight changes and tweaks to it.

All in all, do I recommend this? YES. While it's on sale. If you're reading this when it's not on sale, wait until they apply more fixes to it, then buy it. If they already have applies fixes, and it already is in stable condition, then I can without a doubt recommend this to you at full price.

You're doing a fine job, Nordic Games. Just keep it up, and everything will go smoothly. We, the Darksiders community, believe in you.

reviewText: Best platformer Ive ever played a LONG while. Maybe since Prince of Persia: Sands of Time and Prince of Persia (2008). Screenshots never do this game justice. The chosen art style is quite beautiful and the soundtrack by Jasper Kyd is phenomenal. Im so glad a PC-focus publisher, Nordic, bought this IP from the bankrupt THQ and updated the engine to be a far better port than the original. I hope this game helps fund Darksiders 3.\n\nAs of 11/6/15 the reviews are filled with ungrateful and entitled idiots who cant appreciate either the free game they received or the massive 80% discount to owners of the original version. What they dont realise is if this was a console publisher then the price would truly reflect a greedy pricetag which this one doesnt.

reviewText:
Stay as far away as possible from this version of the game.
The stuttering is unbearable, even on minimum graphic settings on a PC that perfectly meets the recommended requirements. Crashes when changing the graphic setting, resulting in further multiple crashes before being able to restart the game again.
Do the 'improved visuals' make up for the technical issues? Not even remotely. Where rocks used to look sharp and textured, they now appear like smooth plastic. Where colours used to be vibrant and appealing, they now changed to washed out hues that do no longer convey the same atmosphere. A few added grass blades are simply not enough.
Do not invest any money in this edition of the game, rather buy the original if you do not own it yet. If you already do...just don't get this sorry excuse for a remake.

reviewText:
I received this version for free because I own the original version with all the DLC. This game is the same as Darksiders 2 with all the DLC except it has an HD make over and it also has some bug fixes and loot tweaks. I see a lot of reviews giving this game a bad rating simply because they didn't receive this version completely free which is just lame in my opinion. Depending on which version of Darksiders 2 you own you either got a free copy or a discount of up to 80% off.

Now as far as the game goes it's a very fun game with some issues. My biggest issue is with the camera. The camera doesn't always go where it should be. This games uses dashes and rolling manuvers instead of a blocking system, so sometimes when you roll away from an enemy it takes a second for the camera to catch up (you can move the camera manually). The games HD make over looks and runs nice on my I5 laptop with my 6 gigs of ram and 1 gig dedicated video card.

The gameplay is borrowed from some very popular games.In this sequel you play as War's brother Death. Most of the fighting and combo mechanics are borrowed heavily from God of War. The movement and wall systems are borrowed from Assassin's Creed or Prince of Persia. As Death you can run along walls grab pillars jumping from rock to rock. the games dungeons and puzzles are clearly Zelda inspired. I see alot of people say this is a zelda clone. I feel it's more like God of War than Zelda. If you are looking for a Zelda like game I suggest Oceanhorn it's a full zelda tribute (as close as you can get to a Zelda game on PC).

All in all this a great game with Bosses, Gear, Skills, and Weapon upgrades. If you don't own Darksiders 2 and all the DLC this is the version to buy. This is a great game that failed to fix some minor problems with game play and camera issues, but doesn't take away from the game as a whole. Bottom line if you like God of War, Assassin's Creed, & Zelda this is a game for you.

7.5 / 10

reviewText:
If darksiders is the future of video gaming, I dont want to be a gamer anymore. The combat consists of three buttons, attack 1, attack 2, and dodge. Once you learn to unlock your camera and dodge roll behind an opponent as he's winding up an attack, the game may as well give you the end credits. That is of course after you learn the abysmal consol port controls, and you will have to learn them. The game treats you like a baby with it's graphical options, the most advanced option avalable is Vsync on/off. Suffers from crashing, severe hitching, low-poly dated graphics, combat so patheticly shallow super smash brothers rip offs have less ♥♥♥♥-takeing simplicity, aids and ebola.

The story isnt entertaining, none of the characters likable, the game's progression boils down to 9 tedious fetch quests, the platforming is out of place and mediocre at best even with a third party perspective, using any weapon that requires use of the lock on is unusable with mouse and keyboard, as it will change your mouse from looking around, to a mouse cursor on a static screen as you're still moving around being attacked, prompted to aim and shoot by clicking on them without even being able to turn.

DO NOT buy this game. Do not buy any darksiders games. Even if you take away all the technical issues, give it visuals better than a university student's exam result and update proper PC controls, the experiance would still be as bland as eating your own snot.

reviewText:
Until it has been patched do not get this game.

Since this is a re-release, I will simply address the problems I encountered in the time that I've played the game.

The Cons:

1. Aim Mode
The biggest problem I encountered was Aim Mode. In the first dungeon, the Cauldron, you have to throw shadow bombs at switches in order to progress, which means going into Aim Mode. For some reason the sensitivity in Aim Mode is exponentially higher then when normally moving the camera, so moving the mouse like you normally would has the camera doing 1080 turns. After looking online and messing with settings extensively, I settled with having the aim sensitivity around a quarter of the bar and switching my mouse's DPI to 400 and moving extremely carefully whenever I had to use Aim Mode. Hopefully there will be a fix for this.

2. Controls/Key Bindings (My god this game needs a manual)
Some of the games key placement are uncomfortable, like dodge being on alt.
I personally started using my thumb on alt and got used to it, but others may find simply re-binding the keys to be easier. However, re-binding can be a hassle in itself. Due to the fact that you can not bind a key to another if an action is already bound to it, simply switching between two keys means binding the first to an unbound key, binding the second to the first, and then binding the first to the second. There's also the fact that there are multiple keys that are already bound against your knowledge, so finding an unbound key in the first place becomes more difficult.

3. Actions/Executions
The game doesn't explain about several mechanics in the game, some of them literally being key to move on.
Interacting with a person/object seems elementary, yes? But other then an icon popping up and telling me I could do an action, I wasn't told that E" was interact. In fact I had to look online for this answer
date: and despite thinking I was an idiot for doing so
recommended: saw several forum posts of people asking this same question.\nSimilar to this is executions. Executions are animated instant kill strikes that restore all your gauges (health
voteText: reaper) and have increased chances to drop gear. This isn't a problem on console since the button you have to press appears over the enemy when you can execute it
helpfulPercent: but on PC you simply see a red circle and wonder "What the hell does that mean?"
votesHelpful:
again not being told that the interact key solves the question.

4. Frames
There have been other reviews stating the game stutters
votesFunny: and drops frames. The only thing that I saw was frames skipping from turning on default sensitivity due to the speed. Putting on V-Sync and lowering the sensitivity for Aim Mode seemed to get rid of this.\n\nIt should also be noted that upon entering the tutorial dungeon
commentsCount: the Crowfather's palace
column16:
my display drivers crashed. Everything worked fine when I reloaded the game and I was able to continue onward.

Overall I highly recommend you wait till patches come out and fix these and any other problems that may be prevalent in this game.

P.S. On a side note
column17: I personally love the Darksiders series and can't wait for further entries. Hopefully they'll be more PC friendly in the future.\n\nHere's a link to my pc specs if you were wondering: http://pcpartpicker.com/p/KggcXL"

reviewText:
Where to start...

Of all the games to remake, darksiders II is the last to come to mind. It was perfectly stable and well optimised, the graphics quality wasn't anything to complain ablout, and it had something resembling a plot. This "reworked" version has increased the texture quality, at the expense of everything else that actually matters. Changing anything in the settings crashes the game, the camera sensitivity is way too high, even on the lowest setting, making guns useless, and the "improved graphic rendering engine" results in pathetic frame rates, especially with vsync.

Honestly, if you want to play darksiders II, get the original.

reviewText:
Okay, lots of negative reviews going out because of this max shadow crash.
HOW TO FIX THIS *may not work for some people*
Go to your ORIGINAL Darksiders II and load in your game, once you're in you just set the shadows all the way down in the settings and save and quit. This will transfer to the Dethinitive Edition.
DO NOT MAX SHADOWS
Keep the shadows one setting under max, then apply it
IT WILL CRASH ONCE MORE, THEN YOU'RE GOOD TO GO
Hopefully with this fix people can actually upvote the game and actually be able to play it.
Looking for a way to fix it if you don't have the original, hopefully I can find a way.
*side note* Once you get it fixed, do not tamper with anything more, keep the settings how they are. I tampered too much and now I can't seem to get back into the game.

reviewText:
So I read all the negative reviews on here, and saw that the main problem causing all the crashing seemed to be the shadows max setting.  For only $6 i decided to try it, never beat the 2nd one and was interested in it on the Xbox One so PC would be even better!

Game loaded fine first try, even transfered my saved data from the orginal pc release.  I played around a bit, game played super smooth and the cleaned up textures are noticable but not jaw dropping.  So then I went into the graphics settings (which are still bare bones) and noticed everything was maxed, even shadows.  I decided to lower the shadows one notch, as recommend by are friends on Steam, just to be safe.  The diffrence in quality is barely noticeable.  So far so good!

Game plays at a solid 60 fps at 1440p with no problems at all. Not a single crash. Very happy with this, and can wait for the stupid shadow bug to be fixed. Definitely the best way to play this game, and if u haven't played this game before it's worth a look.  Zelda meets God of War, with a biblical story of Armaggedon and the four horsemen!  The art style is great, and the better textures and lighting make this the best way to play.

Don't be put off by all the bad reviews, which are the main reason for this review, because this game is absolutely worth a purchase!  Here's hoping for DarkSiders 3!!

played on : i5 4670k OC @ 4.2
GTX 970
16 Gb RAM
WIn 7 64bit

reviewText:
**Updated review**
There've been three patches since this game was launched and they have addressed all the major complaints I've had.  This version is now equal in stability and performance to the original release, and has slightly better graphics.

**Original Review**
Was a big fan of Darksiders and Darksiders 2.  I've played Darksiders all the way through maybe four or five times, and have played through Darksiders 2 three times prior to this remastered version.

Game immediately crashes upon starting.  Have to reset settings and lower shadow quality.  Why I need to not max out shadow quality on this graphical remastering makes no sense and should never have been launched with this issue.  Started a new game and played through to the start of the cauldron.  The camera feels shakier".  I had just started a new game on the original release a week ago
date: and re-launched it at the same starting area and it doesn't feel "shaky".\n\nI had a cutscene that I couldn't use space to skip dialogue in.  Was the first time I tried
recommended: so I thought maybe the button was changed.  I pushed a bunch of buttons on the keyboard and mouse to no avail.  When the cutscene finished
hoursPlayed: I spent the next ten minutes watching Death roll around and swinging as every queued up button press was executed post cutscene.  After ten minutes I gave up and restarted the game.\n\nNot happy with having to buy this for $6 because I don't own a combo pack.  Overall after an hour or so of play I don't really see this as being worth it for someone who already has Darksiders 2.  The graphical improvements are OK
voteText: but not worth spending money on.  The only reason I am giving this game a thumbs up is that people buying this may help with getting a Darksiders 3 created

reviewText: I downloaded and installed Darksiders II and the game seamlessly synced my current game status without a problem.  The graphics and updated textures look really amazing on my Alienware Alpha.  I seen most negative reviews, but they didn't capture what really was negative about the game.  At 1080p, the game plays just fine with some stutter, but this may be due to the monitor that I'm using.  This edition really shows some improved graphical areas of the game; the Maker's Forge has some really nice textures that helps the eyesight when viewing darker areas.  Outstanding job Gunfire!!!

reviewText:
Update - The devs have already fixed the crash when shadows were set to high and fixed an antialiasing bug.  They also implemented a nice feature to let you reset the game settings at launch if you need to just in case anyone runs into a similar problem where a game setting caused a problem for them.  Buy this game.  Seriously.  If you haven't played it, you probably ought to.  It's woefully underrated.



Supposedly there are bugs.  I'm confident the devs will fix the issues that people are having  (e.g. with the shadow setting right now -- I haven't run into any problems yet with shadows on medium).   I think that, in general, this edition looks significantly better than the original release, although there's a moment early on in the game where I think the lighting may have given an ever so slightly more epic feel in the original release.

The important thing is that if this game looks like it might be your thing, it probably is and the first game is good too.  The controls, graphics, audio, gameplay and story on both games are really solid, with good-to-great voice acting.  If you like any of the Legacy of Kain games, I really can't recommend this and the first Darksiders enough.

Yes, it'd be nice if no one who owned the previous release had to pay for this upgrade, but it IS an upgrade that required developer and artist labor and the publisher needs to capitalize on this update in order to fund future development in the series since they bought the property from THQ and got none of any profit that THQ got from the original's sales.   Please understand that the publisher literally can't afford to just give it away for free and they are giving hefty discounts to people with the previous release.  I bet the people on the Xbox One and the PS4 aren't getting any such favors.

This game is great and it deserves a sequel (preferably w/ 4-player Co-op) and we're probably not going to see that sequel if the publisher can't get a bit of capital out of this release, so please ignore all the people whining about how they're not getting something for free.
