reviewText:
Disclaimer, I got this game for free because I had bought the complete package earlier on sale. I didn't play the first very much because I didn't like it, and haden't tried 2 yet.

I was initially surprised about all the negative reviews on here, since in the start I had no problems. The game is really good and fun. Then I came over more and more bugs and flaws, and I just can't recommend the game in it's current state.

Some bugs/big downsides:
- When changing video settings, you have to restart the whole game.

- When changing mouse sensitivity, the game freezes on a white background and you have to close it.

- Climbing on whines is often bugged in a way that you have to spam wasd in a dirrection to move because you won't move when holding the button down. It looks like the engine is treating it as many small whine-walls instead of one bigger one.

- In 7 hours, I had 2 random crashes. And I often crashes if I alt + tab. I use 2 monitors, and just moving the mouse over to the other monitor and clicking on Chrome to select it, does not crash the game.

- I can not progress the game any further because of a bug that is crashing the game everytime. When I follow the storyline and have to collect a certain key from a certain angel, if I let the cutscene play normally, the game crashed after a minute or two at the same spot, if I try to skip the scene, the game crashes right away. There's no way around this bug that I have found so far.

- The sound settings volum doesn't adjust certain sounds and scenes. The recap in loading screen when you start the game from a save is quite loud, some random sound effect are loud, and some boss cut-scenes are loud. I don't want to change Windows volum, since I often do more things while gaming.

Some general pros and cons:

Pros

+ The fighting in the game is one of it's best features, lots of comboes, different attack styles, special weapon abilities and dodging. When fighting bosses you have to observe and learn how to fight the boss you're facing, or you'll die.

+ Loot balance is good, different levels and rarities drop from all kinds of enemies and chests.

+ Fast travel and a decently large world.

+ Background music

+ No loading screens besides when you fast travel and teleport"

+ Cool VFX

Cons

- Bugs

- The world is restricted
date: it's not open-world in the sence of WoW or Skyrim. There's also only characters that affect the main storyline
recommended: which doesn't help with the world building.\n\n- Side quests are (so far
hoursPlayed: 7 hours in) only collecting certain items along the main storyline
voteText:
there's no additional stories or fights. Also a downside for world building.

- A lot of people say they can't even run the game. For me it's not running too bad. (when it doesn't crash)

- Some inconsistencies in what cutscenes you can skip
helpfulPercent: I can often only skip the scenes I want to watch
votesHelpful:
like those with story.


I will update this review if bugs are fixed until I am able to finish the game. If the game is updated to stop it from crashing and I can actually proceed in the story
votesTotal: I will recommend it with a warning of the other problems."

reviewText:
This is a remastered version of one of my favorite games and franchises, Darksiders II. The Deathinitive Edition offers an additional difficulty level, improved visuals (especially lighting), and rebalanced loot and enemies.

If you've already played Darksiders II before, it's the same game you know and love but prettier. If you've never played Darksiders II, it's a wild ride and a very challenging experience. The combat is visceral and the controls tight and responsive. There are some minor camera issues but you'll learn to adjust to the controls (gamepad highly recommended).

Players new to the series should start with and beat Darksiders I first, before moving onto this title, to get the full breadth of the detailed and winding story. The Darksiders franchise offers a lot to love, from the art and music direction to the weapon skills and enemies. Darksiders II picks up the torch and never slips up.

This is one game (franchise) I highly recommend. This remaster in particular is 100% faithful to the original and definitely a good bit harder and prettier.


Technical Issues
1. [FIXED] Settings Shadows to max crashes the game upon loading or creating a save.
2. Resetting options to fix CTD clears Nightmare Mode from available New Game difficulties.

reviewText:
OK So for starters I haven't beaten the game, original or Deathinitive. I got the franchise pack on sale earlier this year. I was pleasantly surprised today that the Deathinitive edition was coming to PC already, let alone that I got it free (yes I know that some people who got the steam version and the DLC for it did not get it free and that sucks, like, really sucks), but I noticed that the game has a lot of negative reviews on steam, mostly for framerate issues and crashes upon loading a save.

For starters, the crashing upon loading a save is due to issues with maxed out shadows. I don't know why this happens but you can easily turn it down a notch in the old Darksiders II and it should work (it did for me). If you don't have the original version and you max out shadows I'm certain there's a way to edit options.dopt to fix it. The shadow quality is still much higher than the blocky shadow textures in the original version regardless.

Another issue I came across was that the resolution was much higher than it was supposed to be. and since my resolution before was 3840x2160 it resulted in me only being able to see a quarter of the screen. I set the game to 1080p fullscreen before switching back and it worked fine after that. Not sure which of the 2 fixed it though.

As for framerate issues (note that I only tested in the City of the Dead, it's where my save file was when the Deathinitive edition released) I have a GTX 980 running the game at 3840x2160 windowed (forced borderless) with second highest shadow quality, no anti aliasing, and anistrophic filtering on. My framerate didn't drop below 50 during gameplay. That's not great for a game with limited graphics options but you can lower other things. This may just be my graphics card and it may be a serious plague to people with less powerful GPU's (even at 1920x1080) but I can't say for certain.

As far as improvements go it's mostly graphical (although I do like the graphical improvements quite a bit) but I feel like the aiming controls with a controller improved a lot. Before if I did light flicks to position my cursor precisely every 3rd flick would send the cursor flying, screwing up my aim. Fortunately that is no longer an issue. And I don't know if this is typical for remasters of PC games (on PC) but my save file did carry over to the deathinitive edition, which was a nice surprise for me. And of course the game is still very solid on it's own merits. Not the greatest PC port, or PC remaster but it's servicable and the game itself is great. If nothing else it's a better PC port than the one the first Darksiders got.

reviewText:
To me the Deathinitive Edition is a definite improvement over the original game. The images seem a lot sharper and the combat is very smooth. And the loot system is so much more balanced it seems. I'm still in the first part of the game, but I haven't become over encombered by loot yet, which is a problem I had in the original game. I'm looking forward to experiencing the rest of the game.

Yes, there is a crash issue. But for me it was easily fixed by a suggestion made in the discussions.

Please, consider this game if you liked the first games. Or if you just like adventure type games. I know a lot of reviews are being posted by fans who already own the game that are upset they aren't getting a free game or bigger discount, but please ignore them. Those people are behaving like entitled brats. The game is worth the money.

reviewText:
Well well no game escapes the horrible launch nowadays?
The game have a few bugs on launch day: fps drops, constant crashes if you touch the shadows in options (fixed as of today).

The game (for me at least) looks up-to-date. I really like how it looks cleaner but still have the same feel to it, but its up to personal preference. As advice you should look up a video on it on youtube to see how it changed, for me its a big plus. The lights and textures looks nice, nothing feels out of place so far (got to the forge on the makers world).

summa: It is a good buy for 6 euro (played the base), and if you didnt played it before and don't have the game I think you should give it a try after the bugs have been patched out of course. It's for 30 euro and you get all the content too.

reviewText:
Darksiders 2 is a briliant game, combining bits of Devil May Cry, Zelda, Soul Reaver, Diablo, Prince of Persia and even Portal into one stylish comic book fantasy hack em up.


but this remastered version has been a buggy mess for me.

I played Darksiders 2 when it originally came out (in 2013 i think), and loved it, but the hardware i had at the time couldn't handle it well. I always wanted to go back and play this again with a better rig, and lo! this deathfinitive edition popped up in my steam out of nowhere.  Improved textures?  yes please.

from what i've played, the game know has a sleek coat of paint and looks brilliant.  but i can't seem to play for more than 30 mins without it crashing or freezing.  ah, guess i'll have to boot up the regular version then :(  I got this for free, coz i already had the franchise pack, but seriously darksiders 2 is a dang fine IP and deserves MUCH BETTER than this.

Maybe it has been working fine for you, and thats great if it did.  But it just don't work for me, and from a lot of the reviews i've seen this seems to be the case.

Nordic Games, I hear you did this dethfinitive stuff to see if there is interest in the franchise.  Well, I'm defo down for another darksiders game of the original devs do it, but i'm not up for a buggy and sloppy cash grab like this.

reviewText:
Update: 11/22/15

So I've been playing this remaster edition of DS2 for a while and I'd like to say the game is actually better than what I thought previously. Although it had some really nasty bugs during its initial release, the developers had fixed them (at least in public beta) and now it runs very well on my laptop.
Current Issues: They are small and do npt pose serious problems to pro gamers.
a) On your way to the Drenchfort, there's a chance that you will fall infinitely and eventually die while you're riding the horse.
b) The Makers' chest area (Aylia) seem to have a resolution issue, since its texture was not smooth but made of chunks of small squares.
c) The game wouldn't stop running after you exit sometimes. It happens occasionally when you've played the game for several hours.
Let's talk about the pros:
Besides the apparent better texture and shaders, the gameplay system in this remastered edition  is well-balanced. Old players won't really appreciate the beauty of it until the later stage of the game. I personally had complained about not being able to access my DLC weapons instantly before. Now I actually think it is a well-considered idea to let players gain access to them when the time is right". Trust me
date: it makes the gameplay so much smoother
recommended: because you get to use better weapons and armors when you really need them.\n\nComment: Changed my opinion from Not Recommend to Recommended. Still
hoursPlayed: looking forward to seeing the developers improve the game further."
voteText: November 7, 2015

reviewText:
I'm going to preface this with a tl;dr: if you liked Darksiders II, the Deathinitive Edition is literally the same game.  It has an additional, harder difficulty, but the biggest change is a new coat of paint.  If visuals don't warrant the asking price for you, there's no need to upgrade, although this edition does come with all of the DLC.

That said, the game is very good.  Being an old vet, I went straight to the Deathinitive difficulty and found it genuinely challenging.  At times, I thought that certain enemies were unfairly tough, especially in optional dungeons, but the game is still fun and rewarding.  If you're coming from the original version, the mechanics are unchanged and you can still infinitely combo pop-ups to aerials to lock enemies and heal for free with the Black Demise weapon, use that info how you will.

The distribution of unique items is, I think, changed a bit, but I may be remembering wrong.  The Crow, Maker, Angel, and Shadow sets are now found in hidden chests or as rewards instead of distributed at the Serpent's Tome.  The sidequests are largely the same.

Speaking of, the sidequests are unchanged, and thus still absurdly tedious.  Chasing stonebites is a pain, as it always has been, while the rest are go here
recommended: come back".  Not worth it for completionist types
hoursPlayed: but they do provide tangible rewards for those that do.\n\nStill
voteText: the combat is clean
helpfulPercent: the world is interesting if not vast
votesHelpful: and some of the later puzzles are legitimately clever.  Clearing dungeons requires more button skill than cleverness
votesTotal: while secret hunting requires a good amount of both.  The narrative
votesFunny: while not great
commentsCount: at least makes the player's short-term goals clear.  It's a fun game to pick up
column16: and for me has been worth it for four runs so far across the two editions."

reviewText:
TLDR; 7/10. Fun hack 'n' slash combat, great storyline & voice acting but broken game.

I haven't played other games from this series yet but I'm really enjoying this one. I bought this on sale in a pack and hoped against hope that my luck with glitchy games would hold out to at least tolerable glitch levels. However, I can't get as much playtime as I would like to due to control issues:

*sticky controls/slow response (especially SHIFT to focus)
*after saving/opening menus, some keys randomly don't work or character does not respond at all to controls
*sometimes controls just stop working entirely for no reason regardless of opening/closing menus.

For a while I was able to 'resolve' it most of the time by restarting my game. Cool cool no problem until it started taking me back to a random older save, usually 1 to 3 saves back. Very glad playing RPGs have taught me to save frequently so it's not that much of a hassle to catch up.

My laptop more than meets the required specs so I don't think it's my hardware. Steam games are pricey for me (even on sale bc currency exchange rate) and I'm pretty bummed out that I can't keep playing this super fun game :(

reviewText:
Darksiders II = Zelda + jumping + leveling up.



To be more serious, Darksiders II is the game that matches Zelda in its fundamentals (dungeons, puzzles, monsters and bosses), but successfully develops its own theme and style.

This game is better than Zelda in the following ways:
* More intense battles. Death has a surprising large number of different moves, creating endless possibilities for combos, delivering an action battle experience comparable even to that of Devil May Cry.
* More wall action. Death can run along or jump off from walls, an ability that makes walls much more than room dividers.
* Level system, equipments and quest system.

On the other hand, Darksiders II is inferior to Zelda in the following ways:
* Limited camera adjustment. In aiming mode you cannot aim more than about 45 degrees up or down from horizontal. When clinging to walls, sometimes the camera is in such an awkward position that you cannot see the next target that you should jump to, and it's almost not movable at all, leaving you wondering if you hit a dead end.
* Focusing on one enemy does not stop others from attacking. Yes I know that Zelda: Ocarina of Time did this because player had little control over camera position, and in Darksiders II now we have that control. However here the camera is so close to Death that, at any time a forgotten enemy may jump out from behind the camera and give Death an unforeseen, unavoidable attack. It feels not fair.
* Crashes, glitches and soft locks. There had been once when I got locked in a room, because one enemy failed to appear, and I was supposed to defeat that enemy to proceed. Just imagine how much time I wasted examining everything in the room.

In conclusion, I do see the developers paying tribute to Zelda games (heavily so). They did learn and copy the Zelda spirit perfectly, throwing in their own creativity here and there, but there are also unignorable problems that affect the player experience. Had improvements been made, this game could become perfect.

+ Zelda elements
+ Intense battles
- Awkward camera
- Glitches
7 out of 10, good.

reviewText:
UPDATE 25.05.2016

First this game is like playing Portal, I'm not the average FPS player but after a while some puzzles are becoming annoying and ridiculous. Sometimes the enemies are killing you from a bunch of blows and you can't react, on deathinitive difficulty you can say that you play Dark Souls, you need to be a bit careful in choosing your gear and build. The controls are a bit broken, they don't respond sometimes and this can be very difficult when you need to execute your enemies for example, pressing the E key multiple times don't help to much. The grafic on this version is very nice but it's still suffering from flickering and other glitches, the music is nice and the sound can be bugged sometimes. I still recommend this game if you can get it a little cheaper on a sale or something. I tested this game on Win 10 and is working very good, most of the crashes I had were from alt+tab.

reviewText:
26-Apr-2016 : Finished main story + extras
Equipment : MSI GT80-2QE Notebook

REVIEW :
Lots of improvement compared to the 1st game. First, the genre, while the 1st game is more a standard hack n slash action game, this one is more like a simplified RPG game. It combined all the good things from legacy games such as: Soul Reaver, Devil May Cry, and... Portal.

Compared to the 1st game, this one has longer story, great voice acting, better game mechanics, bigger and more varied maps, different gears to loot from chests, inventory management, and of course better graphics. The game design (maps, characters, puzzle, gears) shows how the developer really put their best effort into it. I'm looking forward to Darksiders III.

CONCLUSION :
Recommended on full price, a must-have on sale price.

reviewText:
Darksiders II = Zelda + jumping + leveling up.



To be more serious, Darksiders II is the game that matches Zelda in its fundamentals (dungeons, puzzles, monsters and bosses), but successfully develops its own theme and style.

This game is better than Zelda in the following ways:
* More intense battles. Death has a surprising large number of different moves, creating endless possibilities for combos, delivering an action battle experience comparable even to that of Devil May Cry.
* More wall action. Death can run along or jump off from walls, an ability that makes walls much more than room dividers.
* Level system, equipments and quest system.

On the other hand, Darksiders II is inferior to Zelda in the following ways:
* Limited camera adjustment. In aiming mode you cannot aim more than about 45 degrees up or down from horizontal. When clinging to walls, sometimes the camera is in such an awkward position that you cannot see the next target that you should jump to, and it's almost not movable at all, leaving you wondering if you hit a dead end.
* Focusing on one enemy does not stop others from attacking. Yes I know that Zelda: Ocarina of Time did this because player had little control over camera position, and in Darksiders II now we have that control. However here the camera is so close to Death that, at any time a forgotten enemy may jump out from behind the camera and give Death an unforeseen, unavoidable attack. It feels not fair.
* Crashes, glitches and soft locks. There had been once when I got locked in a room, because one enemy failed to appear, and I was supposed to defeat that enemy to proceed. Just imagine how much time I wasted examining everything in the room.

In conclusion, I do see the developers paying tribute to Zelda games (heavily so). They did learn and copy the Zelda spirit perfectly, throwing in their own creativity here and there, but there are also unignorable problems that affect the player experience. Had improvements been made, this game could become perfect.

+ Zelda elements
+ Intense battles
- Awkward camera
- Glitches
7 out of 10, good.

reviewText:
Overall I will give this game a 5/10. It was on sale for $3.00 when I bought it on a Steam sale. If you look at buying this game at all, I reccomend waiting until it goes on sale. While the game was fun and kept my attention, I am still rating this with a thumbs down because of the many down sides to the game. The game crashed on me several times throughout my playthrough, probably once every 2-3 hours worth of gameplay at various points in the game. While there are a few sidequests you can pick up pretty late into the game, the main storyline is quite linear. And while Darksiders 1 was a very pure game at heart with it's combat and puzzle solving, Darksiders 2 attempted to give more of an RPG feel to it's game. Unfortunately, I don't think it did much to add to the game at all. The leveling is nothing more than arbitrary, and  the random loot drops are needless and excessive in most cases.

The puzzle solving was fun for the first half of the game, however, at a certain point the game just felt like it kept dragging on and on. You meet a new NPC, and he needs you to go run an errand for him, and then after spending an hour going to collect a few things for the NPC, you go meet another NPC and it's just rinse and repeat, even 15-20 hours later.

The biggest negative for me was about 19 hours into the game, I ran into a very serious crash bug during a cutscene at Archon's citadel. Restarting the game didn't help, the crash occured in the same place. Skipping the cutscene didn't help, would crash immediately. Checked the forums, and the devs said that they found an issue and would patch it asap, however, that was a post from 3 years ago, and clearly the game was never patched to fix it. Many people reported that leveling up, or talking to a few different NPC's fixed the issue for them, but I had no such luck. So I am done with this game. This is even the new shiny Deathinitive edition, and it still had many crash issues. Disappointing.

However, I got my money's worth from the game. All said, if you are looking for a cool puzzle solving game like Zelda with the combat of God of War, perhaps this is a game for you. But if you hate games that make you feel like I've been here and done this a hundred times before"
date: then pass this one on by."

reviewText:
TLDR; 7/10. Fun hack 'n' slash combat, great storyline & voice acting but broken game.

I haven't played other games from this series yet but I'm really enjoying this one. I bought this on sale in a pack and hoped against hope that my luck with glitchy games would hold out to at least tolerable glitch levels. However, I can't get as much playtime as I would like to due to control issues:

*sticky controls/slow response (especially SHIFT to focus)
*after saving/opening menus, some keys randomly don't work or character does not respond at all to controls
*sometimes controls just stop working entirely for no reason regardless of opening/closing menus.

For a while I was able to 'resolve' it most of the time by restarting my game. Cool cool no problem until it started taking me back to a random older save, usually 1 to 3 saves back. Very glad playing RPGs have taught me to save frequently so it's not that much of a hassle to catch up.

My laptop more than meets the required specs so I don't think it's my hardware. Steam games are pricey for me (even on sale bc currency exchange rate) and I'm pretty bummed out that I can't keep playing this super fun game :(

reviewText: Having enjoyed Darksiders, I was looking forward to this the second installment in the franchise. I know it is a different character (Death instead of War) but I think they changed a little too much, and not necessarily for the better. Graphicly it doesn't look any better than the first, yet my Alienware laptop running a 660M graphics card struggles on frame rate and it didn't on the first edition. It took a while to find an input arrangement I liked, this was not the case with the first one. But once I got used to the differences, I started getting into the game. The addition of controller support improved things, but as I had got used to keyboard and mouse with Darksiders I reverted back to them instead. As I write I have about 12 hours of play, and am really getting into the game. I don't understand how this game follows on from the first, (maybe I skipped some important cut scenes) but there is a good blend of puzzle and hack 'n' slash like the first. For the 5 pounds I paid for both games I highly recommend their purchase.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
The original Darksiders 2 was an absolute gem of a game, and The Deathinitive Edition is basically the original game with all of the DLC gear integrated into the game proper. The various pieces of DLC gear are appropriately leveled for when you find them, and a few of them actually level with you. This is in contrast to the original Darksiders 2 in which the player received all of the DLC gear up front as level 5 or level 10 gear that did not level with the player.

The graphics were updated / remastered to compete with current generation console titles, but you will need a High End 2015 Gaming PC or better to run the game with all the new bells and whistles. The game can still be run on older / less powerful machines on lower graphical settings, but you'll basically be getting the 2012 original Darksiders 2 graphics. This isn't necessarily a bad thing. The art and character designs have a 'graphic novel' feel to them, so even at lower resolutions the visuals look pretty decent.

The combat and exploration mechanics are still the highlights of this game. The controls are intuitive, and the game makes you feel like a badass ninja during exploration and combat. The exploration is similar to the Prince of Persia 'Sands of Time' games. The combat is similar to the original (i.e. pre-reboot) Devil May Cry games. There is one small portion of the game where you're forced to play from an over-the-shoulder 3rd Person Shooter perspective, but that part of the game is (thankfully) fairly short. If you've never played Darksiders 2, the Deathinitive Edition is a solid purchase.

Disclosure: I received Darksiders 2 Deathinitive Edition as a free download because I purchased the Darksiders Franchise Pack" (which included DS 1 & DS 2 & All DLCs for both games) in 2014. The Deathinitive Edition was released in 2015."
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I'm no big Zelda fan even tho I finished one. And when it came to my ears that Darksiders are kinda Zelda's with violence and warcraft-like lore and artistic direction, I couldn't ignore it. This game is a lot of hours of playtime, lot of amazing locations, a brutal and fun bta ballet, and is full of secrets and optionnal goals to achieve (not mentioning steam stuff).
The art is great, but above all DS2 is about loot and customisation in order to find the best fight style for you!
There is also a new game+ and DLCs here, so when you're done with it, you're not really.
Plus the game is challenging, it has some interesting puzzles and most of the time you can go back into places and dungeons to get what you missed.

It's a fair, solid, efficient, long, personnal and epic solo adventure of modern days you shouldn't miss if you're into dungeons, chests, bosses, achievements and badass lore.

That said, this Edition has some issues to be aware of...
It has framerate drops depending the config you play on, and the areas of course.
And it's desaturated af! So If you plan to play it, make sure to apply some SweetFx on it to restore it's true palette, my advice.

reviewText: I had 57 hours on the original Darksiders II when i encountered the bug that crashes your game due to the save file being larger than 300 mb. (This happened after completing the Demon Lord Belial DLC, which was super buggy btw). I bought this version after backing up my original DSII data and was happy to see that it had fixed the one save data bug. The bad news is it added about ten others in the process. Book of the Dead Pages started falling through the floor, audio was desynced at points, and during the Samael boss fight, he simply didn't appear again after one of his teleporting attacks. I encountered these problems after playing through about 90% of the game. (Finished The Black Stone before things started bugging out). Darksiders II is an awesome game, and I don't know if anyone else is having these problems, but it would nice if I was able to complete this legitimately good game without a host of game-crashing bugs halting my progress.

reviewText:
Pretty solid all around. I can only handle it in smaller doses.

It really feels like the writers had 3-4 hours worth of story to tell, but the developers wanted to stretch it out to 30-40. There are so many fetch quests and arbitrary delays that the real story feels like it gets pushed aside frequently.

That said, there are many improvements over Darksiders 1. Interaction between characters is much better, combat feels more balanced, fast travel is implemented (but not to the extent of, say, Skyrim where walking becomes useless after you can teleport anywhere instantly), and enough secrets and side missions to keep things interesting. Upgrading the Posessed Weapons is highly satisfying.
I feel like the economy could be refined a bit more, what with trading/selling items and collectibles.

I described Darksiders 1 as a Zelda-style adventure game for kids in their mid-20's with ADD. Darksiders 2 is much longer, and feels less straightforward.

The art and character designs have a 'graphic novel' feel to them, so even at lower resolutions the visuals look pretty decent.

The combat and exploration mechanics are still the highlights of this game. The controls are intuitive, and the game makes you feel like a badass ninja during exploration and combat. The exploration is similar to the Prince of Persia 'Sands of Time' games. The combat is similar to the original (i.e. pre-reboot) Devil May Cry games. There is one small portion of the game where you're forced to play from an over-the-shoulder 3rd Person Shooter perspective, but that part of the game is (thankfully) fairly short. If you've never played Darksiders 2, the Deathinitive Edition is a solid purchase.

Disclosure: I received Darksiders 2 Deathinitive Edition as a free download because I purchased the Darksiders Franchise Pack" (which included DS 1 & DS 2 & All DLCs for both games) in 2014. The Deathinitive Edition was released in 2015."

reviewText:
So, my first impression- this game is a born ''child'' of two franchises- the wall climbing reminds of Prince of Persia trilogy, the atmosphere- Legacy of Kain:  Defiance, though not so much ''gothic'', and of course- the main character Death who resembles Raziel quite a lot ( thinking more of appearance).

Game is immersive, dynamic & relaxing at the same time, with pleasant, a bit cartoonish graphics, and of course... the music, especially loving ''The Guardian Theme'' - check it out.

This game is so underrated, it makes me sad.

reviewText: A great Deathinitive edition . I bought it on sale for 3Euro , but now , after I played almost 50 hours , I would buy it even for 30. Really nice graphics , gameplay is just amazing , you can choose from many weapons , awesome quests ,the story is pretty much ok , BUT there are some major bugs with the saves , and some in game bugs . So be ready to search it out on the internet , and do not panic . But the overall game is amazing , definitely buy it if you like hack n slash games or you played Darksiders 1 .
